title: Biden Admits His DOJ Is Corrupt
body: President Joe Biden admitted on Sunday that his Department of Justice (DOJ) is “infected” by politics. It’s an admission that’s entirely true — but not for the reasons Biden thinks. Biden issued a blanket pardon for his son Hunter for “offenses against the United States which he has committed or may have committed or taken part in during the period from January 1, 2014 through December 1, 2024.” That means Hunter is off the hook for the federal gun and tax charges he was being prosecuted for, as well as other potential crimes he committed like FARA violations and money laundering. In explaining the unprecedented, decade-long pardon, Biden said he had no choice since the DOJ was corrupted by politics. “I believe in the justice system, but as I have wrestled with this, I also believe raw politics has infected this process and it led to a miscarriage of justice — and once I made this decision this weekend, there was no sense in delaying it further,” Biden said. “I hope Americans will understand why a father and a President would come to this decision.” Biden’s right, his DOJ is corrupt. Under his DOJ, U.S. Attorney David Weiss delayed bringing charges against Hunter despite ample evidence that Hunter failed to pay more than $1.4 million in taxes and lied about drug use on his federal form to purchase a firearm. Biden’s DOJ hand-crafted a sweetheart plea deal for Hunter that eventually derailed after a judge scrutinized the broad immunity it afforded Hunter. The DOJ, as explained by my colleague Jordan Boyd, “specifically choked an IRS investigation and subsequent charging recommendations for Hunter because they feared it would hurt Joe’s chances in the 2020 election.” All of that is corruption — corruption that only stood to benefit Hunter. But as far as victims of the Biden DOJ’s corruption goes, Hunter isn’t one of them. The DOJ’s Jack Smith indicted President-elect Donald Trump twice. One indictment centered around Trump’s questioning of the administration of the 2020 election. (The other was related to Trump’s alleged mishandling of classified documents.) After Smith dragged Trump through the mud and made a mockery of the so-called “justice” system, the Supreme Court torpedoed Smith’s lawfare efforts in July when it ruled that a U.S. president has “absolute immunity” for “actions within his conclusive and preclusive constitutional authority” and “at least presumptive immunity” for all “official acts.” Smith later filed a superseding indictment against Trump, refusing to let the case go because he thought it would hurt Trump’s chances of winning the election. Smith has since dropped the case after Trump’s victory. Biden’s politicized DOJ has also prosecuted nearly 1,500 Americans for protesting the 2020 election, with Attorney General Merrick Garland telling Americans in August to take the prosecutions as a warning about what would happen to them should they raise questions about an election. The DOJ also targeted a group of praying pro-lifers who decided to pray outside of an abortion clinic in the hope that their silent pleas would help save the life of an innocent child. Seven pro-lifers were found guilty of violating the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances (FACE) Act and engaging in a civil rights conspiracy for, as explained by The Federalist’s Beth Brelje, “standing and sitting in front of the door of the Northland Family Planning Clinic” in Michigan in 2020. The DOJ is corrupt and politicized, as Biden correctly pointed out. But the real victims of the DOJ’s perversion of justice are Trump and the American people, not Hunter Biden.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Right  
The article expresses strong criticism of President Biden and his administration's actions, particularly regarding his son Hunter Biden and the Department of Justice. It characterizes the DOJ as corrupt and politicized, which aligns with right-leaning perspectives focused on accountability and skepticism of Democratic leadership. Additionally, the article reflects a favoring of Donald Trump and presents a negative view of Biden's decisions, common themes in right-wing media. Overall, the content and tone indicate a clear rightward bias.
AI Classification Explanation: The article expresses strong criticism of President Biden and his administration's actions, particularly regarding his son Hunter Biden and the Department of Justice. It characterizes the DOJ as corrupt and politicized, which aligns with right-leaning perspectives focused on accountability and skepticism of Democratic leadership. Additionally, the article reflects a favoring of Donald Trump and presents a negative view of Biden's decisions, common themes in right-wing media. Overall, the content and tone indicate a clear rightward bias.
AI Summary:
President Joe Biden acknowledged corruption within his Department of Justice (DOJ), citing political influence affecting legal proceedings. This admission followed Biden's decision to issue a blanket pardon for his son, Hunter Biden, covering potential offenses from January 1, 2014, to December 1, 2024, effectively dismissing ongoing federal gun and tax charges against him. Biden asserted that political interference led to a miscarriage of justice, justifying his pardon as a necessary step. 

Critics point to actions taken by the DOJ under Biden, including delays in prosecuting Hunter for tax evasion and firearm-related lies, suggesting a corrupt system favoring him. The DOJ orchestrated a lenient plea deal for Hunter that crumbled under judicial scrutiny. Additionally, the DOJ has been seen as politically motivated in its prosecutions of individuals connected to the 2020 election and pro-life advocates, raising concerns about its fairness and integrity.

Despite Biden's acknowledgment of corruption, it appears that the actual victims of these politicized processes include Donald Trump and the American public at large, rather than Hunter Biden himself.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article presents criticism of both Joe Biden and the Department of Justice, highlighting concerns about political influence on legal proceedings. However, it seems to lessen the impact of Biden's actions while emphasizing the hardships faced by Trump and the public, suggesting a narrative sympathetic to conservative viewpoints, particularly regarding Hunter Biden's charges and DOJ decisions. This indicates a slight lean towards a leftist perspective, given the acknowledgment of corruption but interpretation that ultimately favors conservative criticism.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article presents criticism of both Joe Biden and the Department of Justice, highlighting concerns about political influence on legal proceedings. However, it seems to lessen the impact of Biden's actions while emphasizing the hardships faced by Trump and the public, suggesting a narrative sympathetic to conservative viewpoints, particularly regarding Hunter Biden's charges and DOJ decisions. This indicates a slight lean towards a leftist perspective, given the acknowledgment of corruption but interpretation that ultimately favors conservative criticism.

title: Barron Trump's Voice Heard in Video for First Time Since He Was Kid
body: Many on social are surprised after watching a newly released behind the scenes video showing Barron Trump talking and greeting people with his father on election night.Art of the Surge, which is produced by Ashokan Studios, provided an inside look to President-elect Donald Trump's 2024 campaign. The platform's profile on X, formerly known as Twitter, posted a video of the youngest Trump son dressed in a suit and shaking people's hands. Another video had previously resurfaced of Barron Trump with a "Slovenian" accent as a small child."Hello, how are you?" Barron Trump, 18, asked someone off camera. "It's very nice to see you."NEW: Behind the Scenes on Election Night with @realDonaldTrump. Only in Season 2 of #ArtOfTheSurge. Coming soon. pic.twitter.com/b78HZa4ucV— Art of the Surge (@ArtoftheSurge) December 5, 2024 Social media users were shocked, noting that it's the "first time I've heard Barron speak" and that Barron Trump's voice "sounds like his dad.""This might be the first time we have EVER heard Barron speak," another social media user commented. "Historic clip!!!"Rhonda Furin, a Republican who ran for governor in California in 2021, commented on Barron's poise within the video."Barron has really come a long way in 8 years," she wrote. "I remember the 2016 Election Night & Inaugeration (sic). Now he's a young man. He's well reserved & intelligent."Jeremy Prime, the founder of Geeks and Gamers, said the "internet about to blow up over this one."Internet about to blow up over this one pic.twitter.com/AO2tXA5NDM— Jeremy Prime (@DDayCobra) December 5, 2024 Barron Trump, who is dressed in a suit with a red and blue striped tie, is also seen in the video shaking hands and talking with CEO of Ultimate Fighting Championship Dana White, who called the young Trump "buddy." The two confirmed to the now President-elect that they had met before. Republican presidential nominee former President Donald Trump, former first lady Melania Trump and Barron Trump listen at an election night watch party at the Palm Beach Convention Center, Wednesday, Nov. 6, 2024, in West Palm... Republican presidential nominee former President Donald Trump, former first lady Melania Trump and Barron Trump listen at an election night watch party at the Palm Beach Convention Center, Wednesday, Nov. 6, 2024, in West Palm Beach, Fla. A video was released showing Barron Trump speaking with Trump supporters on Election Night. More AP Photo/Evan Vucci Trump told White, who recently said he will not be joining the President-elect's administration, that he gave his son a "shout out last night.""The place went crazy," he said. "Barron, Barron."Trump then asked White if he can make Barron "into a player." The crowd around the three started laughing. Read more Steve Bannon issues warning to America's wealthy Matt Gaetz praises three different Democrats within 24 hours Republican calls fears Liz Cheney may be Trump admin target "nonsense" Gavin Newsom responds after 7.0 earthquake hits California The Viral Young Barron VideoA video resurfaced on social media earlier this year showing a then 4-year-old Barron Trump speaking with an accent much like that of his Slovenian-born mother."Here's footage of Barron speaking at the age of 4—with a Slovenian accent," the social media user wrote in part, as they posted the clip taken from an April 2010 appearance that the Trumps made on CNN's Larry King Live.The Daily Mail posted a clip to TikTok showing Trump saying Barron's accent is "great" and that "anything he does is ok." The President-elect's wife, Melania, said it's because the toddler spent time with her and boasts that he speaks three languages. @dailymailA resurfaced clip reveals what Donald Trump REALLY thinks of his son Barron's Slovenian accent. In a 2012 interview with Larry King, the president-elect revealed he thinks Barron's accent is 'great,' and 'anything he does is okay with me.' 🎥 CNN Read the full story on DailyMail.com. #news #politics #trump #donaldtrump #barrontrump ♬ original sound - Daily Mail In the footage, New York City-born Barron Trump is told by his mother to say, "Hi Larry," prompting the youngster to enthusiastically wave to the camera before jumping around his father's office as his parents look on."I like my suitcase," Barron Trump said in clipped tones as he picked up the item. He then asked his mother: "I have to go to school now?""Yeah, you will have lunch and then you go to school," said the president-elect's wife, who immigrated to the U.S. in 1996 and has been married to Donald Trump since 2005.Later on in the clip, the boy is shown kneeling before his open suitcase as his father said: "Now you can do reading, writing, and arithmetic."People took to social media, especially on TikTok, to adlib Barron Trump's video. Others posted videos of their pets getting ready to "go to school now," referencing the viral resurfaced clip.Influential evangelist Reverand Franklin Graham shared the resurfaced video as well in November, noting that the conversation is "one thing we're missing – more parents being parents."This older video from CNN shows @realDonaldTrump giving a young Barron Trump fatherly instruction before he goes off to school. He told him to get all A’s, and when he’s older, no drugs, no alcohol, no cigarettes, and no tattoos! That’s one thing we’re missing—more parents being… pic.twitter.com/40r2dc2V1A— Franklin Graham (@Franklin_Graham) November 19, 2024 Who is Barron Trump?Compared to his siblings, Barron Trump has stayed away from the public eye for the most part, with his parents previously emphasizing their desire to shield him from the spotlight.Barron Trump is the youngest of Trump's five children, born in 2006. He is the only child Trump has had with his current wife, Melania. The youngest Trump child was just 10 years old when his father was sworn in at the White House in 2017.Donald Trump has praised Barron Trump for getting good grades in school and being a great kid. Barron Trump started college at New York University in August after an appearance at his father's rally sparked speculation he might go into politics.Now eligible to vote, Barron Trump appears to be helping his father alongside siblings Donald Trump Jr., Ivanka Trump and Eric Trump, with his father claiming Barron Trump has been influential in reaching younger voters. Barron Trump had told the president-elect on which podcasts to appear and was the main reason his father spoke on Adin Ross and Bussin' With the Boys. He also notably received a standing ovation at one of his father's campaign rallies in July.Barron Trump has also held the role of "Web3 ambassador" with his two brothers in the cryptocurrency business supported by his family, called World Liberty Financial. Donald Trump posted a recent video encouraging people to "embrace this incredible technology."
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Right  
The article predominantly covers Barron Trump, son of former President Donald Trump, in a positive light, emphasizing his accomplishments and interactions on election night. The positive tone and focus on Trump's campaign suggest a favorable positioning towards Trump and the Republican party. Additionally, references to supportive social media comments contribute to the sense that the narrative is being framed to engage a conservative audience. Thus, it aligns with a Right bias.

The positive tone and focus on Trump's campaign suggest a favorable positioning towards Trump and the Republican party. Additionally, references to supportive social media comments contribute to the sense that the narrative is being framed to engage a conservative audience. Thus, it aligns with a Right bias.
AI Summary:
Barron Trump was recently featured in a behind-the-scenes video where he was seen speaking for the first time, surprising many social media users. The video, produced for the series "Art of the Surge," showcases Barron, now 18, dressed in a suit and greeting attendees during his father's election night event. His voice sounded similar to his father's, prompting online comments likening it to "historic" as it was the first time many had heard him speak. 

The video highlighted Barron interacting with various attendees, including UFC CEO Dana White. Donald Trump jokingly remarked about making Barron "into a player" during the event. The article also mentions a resurfaced clip of a young Barron speaking with a Slovenian accent, prompting reflections on his upbringing and language skills. 

As the youngest Trump child, Barron has mostly maintained a low profile. Born in 2006, he is the only child of Donald and Melania Trump. Currently attending college at New York University, Barron has begun to engage more in his father's political activities, influencing his father on appealing to younger voters and participating in campaign events. Barron Trump is also involved in a family-supported cryptocurrency venture.

Center  
The article presents a neutral overview of Barron Trump, focusing on factual details about his recent public appearance and personal background without apparent bias towards or against his family's political stance. The language used is straightforward and avoids emotive language or subjective interpretations, indicating an objective reporting style typical of center-aligned media.

The language used is straightforward and avoids emotive language or subjective interpretations, indicating an objective reporting style typical of center-aligned media.

title: Trump Says Defense Nominee Hegseth a 'Winner'
body: President-elect Donald Trump says Pete Hegseth "is a winner" who has received "strong and deep" support despite mainstream media reports the defense secretary nominee faces an uphill battle to be confirmed by the Senate. According to media reports this week, Hegseth's nomination is in jeopardy due to allegations about his personal and professional life. It even was reported that Trump had zeroed in on several potential candidates to replace the Army veteran and TV personality. Trump on Friday said he is sticking with Hegseth. "Pete Hegseth is doing very well. His support is strong and deep, much more so than the Fake News would have you believe," Trump posted on Truth Social. "He was a great student – Princeton/Harvard educated – with a Military state of mind. He will be a fantastic, high energy, Secretary of Defense, one who leads with charisma and skill. Pete is a WINNER, and there is nothing that can be done to change that!!!" Also on Friday, The Guardian reported that Trump aides have told the president-elect's transition team that they haven't found three Republican senators who are "categorically opposed" to Hegseth's confirmation. Hegseth has been meeting with senators this week in efforts to secure confirmation votes amid allegations of sexual assault and a problematic drinking habit. At the Capitol on Wednesday, Hegseth said he spoke with Trump, who encouraged him to "keep going, keep fighting." Hegseth wrote a Wednesday opinion column for The Wall Street Journal to ostensibly set the record straight and to fight against a "manufactured media takedown." "I look forward to an honest confirmation hearing with our distinguished senators — not a show trial in the press," he wrote. It was reported this week that Trump was considering replacing Hegseth with Florida GOP Gov. Ron DeSantis. Sen. Joni Ernst, R-Iowa, a veteran who also has been mentioned as a possible defense secretary nominee, signaled Thursday that she isn't ready to support Hegseth, Politico reported. Charlie McCarthy ✉ Charlie McCarthy, a writer/editor at Newsmax, has nearly 40 years of experience covering news, sports, and politics.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article predominantly covers Trump's strong endorsement of his defense nominee, Pete Hegseth, portraying him positively in the face of negative media reports and allegations against him. This aligns with a more conservative viewpoint, emphasizing support for Trump and his choices. Furthermore, the language used, such as "Fake News," indicates a alignment with right-leaning rhetoric, catering to a conservative audience. Additionally, the author's affiliation with Newsmax, a known right-leaning media outlet, further supports the classification of this article as Lean Right.
AI Classification Explanation: The article predominantly covers Trump's strong endorsement of his defense nominee, Pete Hegseth, portraying him positively in the face of negative media reports and allegations against him. This aligns with a more conservative viewpoint, emphasizing support for Trump and his choices. Furthermore, the language used, such as "Fake News," indicates a alignment with right-leaning rhetoric, catering to a conservative audience. Additionally, the author's affiliation with Newsmax, a known right-leaning media outlet, further supports the classification of this article as Lean Right.
AI Summary: President-elect Donald Trump expressed strong support for Pete Hegseth, his nominee for Secretary of Defense, amidst allegations regarding Hegseth's personal and professional conduct that may jeopardize his confirmation in the Senate. Despite media reports suggesting a struggle for Hegseth's approval, Trump emphasized on Truth Social that Hegseth is a "winner" and has strong backing. Hegseth, educated at Princeton and Harvard and a veteran, has been actively meeting with senators to secure votes despite challenges, including claims of sexual assault and a drinking problem. Trump previously considered other candidates, including Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, but is committed to Hegseth. Hegseth has publicly addressed his situation, urging for an honest confirmation hearing instead of media scrutiny. Some Republican senators, like Joni Ernst, are still undecided about supporting Hegseth.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article presents information favoring President Trump and his nominee Pete Hegseth, depicting both in a positive light despite the controversies surrounding Hegseth. By emphasizing Trump's strong support and framing the Senate's hesitance as media-driven rather than legitimate concerns, the piece aligns with more favorable views of Republican leadership. The tone and selective focus further suggest a Slight lean towards the right-wing perspective, as it downplays the seriousness of the allegations against Hegseth and portrays his candidacy in a positive context.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article presents information favoring President Trump and his nominee Pete Hegseth, depicting both in a positive light despite the controversies surrounding Hegseth. By emphasizing Trump's strong support and framing the Senate's hesitance as media-driven rather than legitimate concerns, the piece aligns with more favorable views of Republican leadership. The tone and selective focus further suggest a Slight lean towards the right-wing perspective, as it downplays the seriousness of the allegations against Hegseth and portrays his candidacy in a positive context.

title: House Democrat Asks Biden to Give 'Blanket Pardons' to Trump, Patel Enemies
body: Democratic Representative Brendan Boyle has asked President Joe Biden to give "blanket pardons" to individuals on a list of "enemies" created by Kash Patel, Donald Trump's choice to become the next FBI director.Boyle, who represents a congressional district consisting of parts of Philadelphia, sounded the alarm about the "enemies list" included in Patel's book Government Gangsters: The Deep State, the Truth, and the Battle for Our Democracy.In a statement released Wednesday, Boyle wrote that choosing Patel to lead the FBI "made it clear" that the president-elect is "more focused on settling personal scores than on protecting the American people or upholding the rule of law.""The people they're targeting include law enforcement officers, military personnel, and others who have spent their lives protecting this country," he said. "These patriots shouldn't have to live in fear of political retribution for doing what's right. That's why I'm urging President Biden to issue a blanket pardon for anyone unjustly targeted by this vindictive scheme." Democratic Representative Brendan Boyle attends a House Budget Committee meeting on September 20, 2023. On Wednesday, Boyle asked President Joe Biden to issue "blanket pardons" for individuals on an "enemies list" created by Donald Trump's... Democratic Representative Brendan Boyle attends a House Budget Committee meeting on September 20, 2023. On Wednesday, Boyle asked President Joe Biden to issue "blanket pardons" for individuals on an "enemies list" created by Donald Trump's choice to lead the FBI, Kash Patel. More Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images Newsweek reached out via email to the White House and Trump's transition team for comment.The list includes a number of individuals, both Democrats and Republicans, who have publicly sparred with Trump over the years, including former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton, Vice President Kamala Harris, Biden himself and several members of his administration.The list also features individuals who served in Trump's White House but have become Trump critics, such as Alyssa Farah Griffin, his former director of strategic communications and now a co-host of The View, and his former press secretary Stephanie Grisham.Boyle warned that Democrats need to "act with urgency" to resist Trump, who indicated on the campaign trail that he would seek revenge against those he feels unjustly targeted him."If we're serious about stopping Trump's authoritarian ambitions, we need to act decisively and use every tool at our disposal," Boyle wrote. "Norms and traditions alone won't stop him—Trump has shown time and again that he's willing to ignore them to consolidate power and punish his opponents."For his part, Trump has rejected claims that he would seek retribution in his second term. Read more U.S. Politics Adam Schiff Doesn't Want Preemptive Biden Pardon to Protect from Trump FBI Nominee Kash Patel Was Targeted in an Iranian Hack: Report Trump Ally Issues New Warning to Senators After Kash Patel Nomination What Kash Patel Has Said About Releasing Diddy List, Jeffrey Epstein Flight Logs "I am not looking for retribution, grandstanding or to destroy people who treated me very unfairly or even badly beyond comprehension," he said on Fox News in November. "I am always looking to give a second and even third chance, but never willing to give a fourth chance—that is where I hold the line."If confirmed by the Senate, Patel would replace Christopher Wray, whom Trump appointed to lead the FBI in 2017. Patel has made a reputation as a Trump loyalist, serving as senior adviser to the acting director of national intelligence, chief of staff to the acting secretary of defense and an unspecified role with the National Security Council during Trump's first term.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article focuses on a Democratic representative's concerns regarding potential misuse of power by Trump and his allies, highlighting the idea of an "enemies list." The emphasis on calls for accountability and warnings of authoritarianism suggests a clear alignment with left-leaning perspectives. It critiques Trump and Patel while portraying Boyle's requests as necessary for justice, reflecting a tendency to lean left in the political spectrum.
AI Classification Explanation: The article focuses on a Democratic representative's concerns regarding potential misuse of power by Trump and his allies, highlighting the idea of an "enemies list." The emphasis on calls for accountability and warnings of authoritarianism suggests a clear alignment with left-leaning perspectives. It critiques Trump and Patel while portraying Boyle's requests as necessary for justice, reflecting a tendency to lean left in the political spectrum.
AI Summary: Democratic Representative Brendan Boyle has urged President Joe Biden to issue "blanket pardons" to individuals identified on an "enemies list" created by Kash Patel, a proposed FBI director under Donald Trump. Boyle expressed concerns about Patel's list, which includes prominent figures from both parties, such as Hillary Clinton, Kamala Harris, and Biden, as well as former Trump officials who have criticized him. He accused Trump and Patel of prioritizing personal vendettas over national security and protecting the rule of law, highlighting the need for urgency among Democrats to counter Trump’s alleged authoritarian tendencies. Boyle asserted that the targeted individuals, including law enforcement and military personnel, should not live in fear of political retribution. Trump has denied intentions of seeking revenge during a potential second term. If Patel is confirmed, he would succeed Christopher Wray as FBI director.

Left

The framing of the narrative emphasizes the need for Democrats to protect individuals from perceived political retaliation, which is a stance typically aligned with leftist viewpoints.

title: The Great American Acid Trip
body: In 1966, the poet Allen Ginsberg offered a remedy for America’s broken soul: If everyone tried LSD, he said, we would discover “some ray of glory or vastness beyond our conditioned social selves, beyond our government, beyond America even, that will unite us into a peaceful community.” Psychedelics, in other words, could save America.More than half a century later, the nation’s psychedelic movement finds itself with a new figurehead: Rick Doblin. As the founder of the nonprofit Multidisciplinary Association for Psychedelic Studies (MAPS), Doblin has spent decades pushing for the liberalization of access to psychedelics—drugs he believes can cure the world of trauma and usher in a new golden age. His goal, he says, is to create “a world of net-zero trauma by 2070.” Doblin is about to have a new, powerful ally in his quest. Robert F. Kennedy Jr.—the man charged by Donald Trump with “Making America Healthy Again”—is a big believer in the power of psychedelics. He endorsed legalizing them during his presidential campaign. Kennedy sees psychedelic drugs as one of the tools of healing that Big Pharma has tried to keep away from the public—part of a broader alternative medicine agenda. In a recent post on X, the nominee for the nation’s top health post published a list of drugs and therapies he plans to liberate from FDA “suppression.” The first item was psychedelics. America, it seems, is about to get trippy. Or is it? This post is for paying subscribers only Subscribe now Already have an account? Sign in
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article critiques traditional medical approaches and champions the liberalization of psychedelics as a therapeutic avenue, a perspective commonly associated with more liberal or progressive views. It highlights figures like Rick Doblin and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in promoting an alternative to mainstream medicine, aligning with ideals often found in left-leaning narratives that support holistic and unconventional treatments against established practices. The focus on healing trauma through psychedelics further emphasizes a liberal perspective on mental health and drug policy reform.
AI Classification Explanation: The article critiques traditional medical approaches and champions the liberalization of psychedelics as a therapeutic avenue, a perspective commonly associated with more liberal or progressive views. It highlights figures like Rick Doblin and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. in promoting an alternative to mainstream medicine, aligning with ideals often found in left-leaning narratives that support holistic and unconventional treatments against established practices. The focus on healing trauma through psychedelics further emphasizes a liberal perspective on mental health and drug policy reform.
AI Summary: The article titled "The Great American Acid Trip" discusses the resurgence of interest in psychedelics in America, tracing its roots back to Allen Ginsberg's 1966 assertion that LSD could heal the nation's social ills. Today, Rick Doblin, founder of the nonprofit MAPS, leads the charge for wider access to these substances, advocating for the potential of psychedelics to treat trauma and promote a healthier society, with an ambitious goal of achieving "net-zero trauma by 2070." A notable ally in this movement is Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who supports the legalization of psychedelics as part of his agenda to combat pharmaceutical suppression of alternative treatments during his presidential campaign. With powerful figures backing this cause, the article suggests that America may be on the brink of a psychedelic renaissance.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article presents a favorable view of psychedelics, highlighting their therapeutic potential and the support of prominent figures like Rick Doblin and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. It emphasizes the social justice aspect of drug legalization and contrasts this with pharmaceutical suppression, which resonates more with left-leaning ideologies that advocate for alternative medicine and reform in drug policy.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article presents a favorable view of psychedelics, highlighting their therapeutic potential and the support of prominent figures like Rick Doblin and Robert F. Kennedy Jr. It emphasizes the social justice aspect of drug legalization and contrasts this with pharmaceutical suppression, which resonates more with left-leaning ideologies that advocate for alternative medicine and reform in drug policy.

title: Olympics brass upbeat about working with Trump on 2028 Games
body: GENEVA — Olympic leaders are “very confident and relaxed” about working with the incoming Trump administration ahead of the 2028 Los Angeles Summer Games, outgoing IOC President Thomas Bach said Thursday. President-elect Donald Trump has talked up his role in helping land the Games for L.A. in 2017, though a White House meeting during that campaign with an Olympic delegation including Bach was not a success. Still, the two men could meet again as soon as Saturday in Paris, which hosted the 2024 Olympics that L.A. originally bid for. Trump is traveling to the French capital for ceremonies this weekend to reopen Notre Dame Cathedral that was devastated by fire five years ago. Bach also is invited to return to the Olympic host city where he has excellent relations with French President Emmanuel Macron, who formally opened the Summer Games on July 26. President Trump should do the same duty at the L.A. Olympics opening ceremony on July 14, 2028, at SoFi Stadium in Inglewood. Though the L.A. Olympics are privately funded and organized, federal government guarantees and funding are needed for security, as well as providing visas to ensure athletes, coaches and officials from 206 national teams, plus a refugees team, can enter the U.S. to train and compete. Bach said Thursday responsibility for “taking early contact with the incoming team” of the Trump administration is with organizing committee officials in L.A., and leaders of the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee. “We are very confident there with regard to the steps and efforts being undertaken,” Bach said at a news conference after an executive board meeting of the International Olympic Committee in Lausanne, Switzerland. “We saw also that President-elect Trump repeatedly declared his support for the Games, which we never had any doubt because he has declared this support from the very beginning.” On Wednesday, Trump said he appointed Monica Crowley as his representative for “major U.S. hosted events,” including the L.A. Olympics and the 2026 World Cup in men’s soccer. Trump will be invited as head of state by FIFA to present the trophy to the winning captain at the World Cup final. That game is on July 19, 2026, at MetLife Stadium near New York City. “The World Cup and the Olympics, I was responsible for getting both of them, actually,” Trump told Bill Belichick on the “Let’s Go!” podcast before the Nov. 5 election. The U.S. will co-host soccer’s biggest event with Canada and Mexico, having beaten the rival bid of Morocco in a June 2018 vote in Moscow by FIFA member federations. Trump has had a warmer relationship with FIFA President Gianni Infantino, who twice visited the White House in the first administration. They also co-headlined at Davos, Switzerland, in January 2020 in an event on the sidelines of the World Economic Forum. On Thursday, Trump’s video message to FIFA, expressing his “highest regards and respect to Gianni,” was broadcast at the soccer body’s draw ceremony in Miami for the 2025 Club World Cup. It was attended by Trump’s daughter Ivanka and her husband Jared Kushner. The IOC said its commissioned research showed 5 billion people — 84% of the potential global audience aged over 4 years old — followed the Paris Olympics. “These Olympic Games met the expectations of the world,” Bach said.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article presents a positive view of President Trump's involvement with the upcoming Los Angeles Olympics, highlighting his support and interaction with Olympic leaders. The tone is supportive and focuses on collaboration with the Trump administration, which aligns more closely with a lean right perspective. The emphasis on Trump's role and the optimistic quotes from IOC President Thomas Bach further contribute to this classification.
AI Classification Explanation: The article presents a positive view of President Trump's involvement with the upcoming Los Angeles Olympics, highlighting his support and interaction with Olympic leaders. The tone is supportive and focuses on collaboration with the Trump administration, which aligns more closely with a lean right perspective. The emphasis on Trump's role and the optimistic quotes from IOC President Thomas Bach further contribute to this classification.
AI Summary: Outgoing IOC President Thomas Bach expressed optimism regarding collaboration with the Trump administration for the upcoming 2028 Los Angeles Summer Games. Despite a less-than-successful earlier meeting during Trump's campaign, Bach noted that the incoming president has consistently shown support for the Games, which were awarded to L.A. in 2017. Bach will potentially meet Trump in Paris this weekend during events marking the reopening of Notre Dame Cathedral. The L.A. Olympics will require federal guarantees for security and visas for 206 national teams, but Bach indicated that the responsibility for engaging with the Trump administration lies with organizers and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee. Trump has appointed Monica Crowley as his representative for major U.S. events, including the Olympics and 2026 World Cup, which he claims to have played a role in securing. Trump has a favorable relationship with FIFA President Gianni Infantino, highlighting connections at events like the World Economic Forum. The IOC reported that an estimated 5 billion people are expected to follow the Paris Olympics.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Center  
The article provides information about the collaboration between the International Olympic Committee and the Trump administration without expressing strong opinions or biases. It presents facts regarding the meetings, support for the 2028 Los Angeles Games, and relevant figures in a neutral manner, focusing on the logistical aspects and the significance of the events involved. This objective reporting aligns with a centrist approach, avoiding extreme viewpoints or language indicative of a particular political bias.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article provides information about the collaboration between the International Olympic Committee and the Trump administration without expressing strong opinions or biases. It presents facts regarding the meetings, support for the 2028 Los Angeles Games, and relevant figures in a neutral manner, focusing on the logistical aspects and the significance of the events involved. This objective reporting aligns with a centrist approach, avoiding extreme viewpoints or language indicative of a particular political bias.

title: LA 2028 Games enjoy support of incoming Trump administration says IOC
body: The Los Angeles Olympics were awarded in 2017 when Trump was president following his first election victory. Trump also met Bach at the White House in 2017 shortly before the Games were awarded to Los Angeles. While the LA Games do not depend on federal funding like most other Olympics, as the project is privately funded, the federal government plays a key role in providing security, transport and travel assistance amongst other areas of support for the event. "It is in the best hands of the United States Olympic and Paralympic Committee and the organising committee," Bach told a press conference when asked about relations with the new U.S. administration taking over in January. "Whenever they (USOPC) would deem it appropriate the IOC will be at their side. We are very confident with regard to the steps and efforts being undertaken by the organising committee and the USOPC, taking early contact with the incoming team," Bach said. "We saw also that President-elect Trump repeatedly declared the support for the Games, which we never had any doubt (about). He has declared this support from the very beginning." The first Trump administration in 2017 enacted a travel ban targeting several Muslim-majority countries, which the President at the time said was needed to protect the U.S. against attacks by Islamist militants. That had caused concern in the sports world with the Olympics bringing together more than 10,500 athletes from more than 200 countries. Tens of thousands more are foreign support staff, coaches, referees, media and fans from abroad. President Joe Biden ended the travel ban when he took office in 2021. Last month LA Games officials said they had been in contact with the incoming Trump administration and were confident that the U.S. federal government would deliver on its promises to support the Games.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Center  
This article presents information regarding the LA 2028 Olympics and their support from the incoming Trump administration without strong emotional language or apparent bias. It outlines both the historical context of Trump's involvement and mentions the previous travel ban, maintaining a neutral tone. It does not take a definitive stance for or against Trump, instead focusing on the facts surrounding the event and the organizational dynamics. This balanced approach places it in the "Center" category.
AI Classification Explanation: This article presents information regarding the LA 2028 Olympics and their support from the incoming Trump administration without strong emotional language or apparent bias. It outlines both the historical context of Trump's involvement and mentions the previous travel ban, maintaining a neutral tone. It does not take a definitive stance for or against Trump, instead focusing on the facts surrounding the event and the organizational dynamics. This balanced approach places it in the "Center" category.
AI Summary: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) expressed confidence in the support for the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics from the incoming Trump administration. The LA Games, awarded in 2017, are privately funded but require federal assistance for security and transportation. IOC President Thomas Bach emphasized the strong relationship between the organizing committee and the U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee and noted the Trump administration's previously declared support for the Games. Concerns had arisen during Trump's first term due to a travel ban affecting several Muslim-majority countries, which posed potential challenges for international participation. However, following the end of the travel ban by President Biden in 2021, LA Games officials reported they had been in communication with the new administration and remained confident in receiving necessary federal support.

Lean Right  
The article discusses the Los Angeles Olympics in relation to the Trump administration's support, highlighting a preference for positive governmental relations and implicitly supporting the notion of federal involvement in private events. It acknowledges challenges linked to Trump's past policies but ultimately depicts a cooperative stance between Olympic officials and a future Republican government. This inclination towards portraying the Trump administration in a non-negative light aligns more closely with lean right perspectives.

It acknowledges challenges linked to Trump's past policies but ultimately depicts a cooperative stance between Olympic officials and a future Republican government. This inclination towards portraying the Trump administration in a non-negative light aligns more closely with lean right perspectives.

title: Head of Democratic Caucus says thin House margins make attendance vital next year
body: The head of the House Democratic Caucus is sending an early message to his troops heading into the 119th Congress: Attendance will be crucial given the razor-tight margins in the lower chamber. “It’s important for every member to come to work and to do their job. That’s what we’re telling our caucus,” Rep. Pete Aguilar (D-Calif.) said during a press briefing in the Capitol. “Their attendance is incredibly important, and the work that we do here is important, and pushing back against Republican overreach is potentially something that we have to do next year,” he continued. “And in order to do that, we’re going to need them coming” to Washington. While Democrats generally fared poorly in this year’s elections — losing the Senate and White House while failing to flip the House — the party outperformed the top of the ticket in the lower chamber, where GOP leaders will have just a spare 220 to 215 advantage in the next Congress. That thin advantage will get even thinner in the early part of next year, as Reps. Elise Stefanik (R-N.Y.) and Michael Waltz (R-Fla.) are set to join the Trump administration, while former Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-Fla.) — who won reelection last month — has already resigned ahead of his failed bid to lead the Justice Department in Trump’s second term. Those shifts will leave Speaker Mike Johnson (R-La.), who’s expected to keep the gavel in the next Congress, with a hairline 217 to 215 majority for several months of 2025, when President-elect Trump is hoping to use the GOP majorities in Congress to move an ambitious 100-day agenda that includes a sweeping extension of his 2017 tax cuts. The tiny cushion means GOP leaders will have to achieve perfect unity among Republican lawmakers in order to pass their partisan agenda, since even a single defection would lead to a tie — 216 to 216 — which spells failure under House rules. The math changes, however, if there are Democratic absences, which would lower the threshold Republicans would need to pass their bills, thereby padding their cushion to allow more GOP defections. It’s that scenario that Aguilar and other Democratic leaders are already fighting to avoid by encouraging every member to be in the chamber when hot-button legislation hits the floor. The Democratic Caucus chairman said he’s sympathetic to lawmakers who are suffering from serious illnesses, including several with cancer, but quickly emphasized that those members volunteered to seek reelection, even knowing of their health troubles. “That’s life, but members also ran for these jobs,” Aguilar said. “Members ran for these jobs and were reelected knowing that that was what they were experiencing. And if they asked their voters to send them to D.C. to do work, my expectation is that they’re going to come to D.C. to do work. “That’s how I approach it.”
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article primarily features a Democratic lawmaker discussing strategies that emphasize the importance of Democratic attendance in the House to counter Republican policies. While it provides factual information, the framing, focus on partisan dynamics, and emphasis on Democratic efforts suggest a perspective that aligns more closely with Democratic viewpoints. The discourse around "pushing back against Republican overreach" indicates a leaning toward the Democratic narrative rather than a neutral or conservative stance.
AI Classification Explanation: The article primarily features a Democratic lawmaker discussing strategies that emphasize the importance of Democratic attendance in the House to counter Republican policies. While it provides factual information, the framing, focus on partisan dynamics, and emphasis on Democratic efforts suggest a perspective that aligns more closely with Democratic viewpoints. The discourse around "pushing back against Republican overreach" indicates a leaning toward the Democratic narrative rather than a neutral or conservative stance.
AI Summary: Rep. Pete Aguilar, the head of the House Democratic Caucus, has emphasized the importance of attendance for Democratic members in the upcoming 119th Congress due to the slim margins in the House. With Republicans holding a 220 to 215 advantage, the small majority will become even tighter as some GOP members transition to the Trump administration or resign. Aguilar highlighted that every member's presence is crucial for the Democratic party to effectively contest Republican initiatives and to fulfill their duties. He acknowledged the challenges faced by certain members dealing with illnesses, but stressed that they chose to seek reelection and should commit to their responsibilities in Washington. The success of the Democrats in the House is critical, as attendance could affect legislative outcomes and provide the Republicans an opportunity to advance their agenda if Democrats are absent.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Center  
This article focuses on a statement by Rep. Pete Aguilar regarding the importance of attendance for Democratic members in a closely contested House. It presents factual information without overtly promoting a partisan agenda or bias. The language is neutral, emphasizing responsibilities of lawmakers and the potential impact of attendance on legislative outcomes. This objectivity places the article in the "Center" classification.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: This article focuses on a statement by Rep. Pete Aguilar regarding the importance of attendance for Democratic members in a closely contested House. It presents factual information without overtly promoting a partisan agenda or bias. The language is neutral, emphasizing responsibilities of lawmakers and the potential impact of attendance on legislative outcomes. This objectivity places the article in the "Center" classification.

title: To Restore Democracy Trump Will Have To Overcome Administrative State Tyranny
body: In the wake of Donald Trump’s historic victory, permanent Washington’s hysteria is reaching new heights daily. “Federal bureaucrats wrestle with fight-or-flight response to Trump election,” reads one headline. Justice Department officials are “terrified,” according to another, fearing they may be sidelined, fired, or unable to “resist” as they did during the president’s first term. Pentagon officials are reportedly preparing their response to orders to “deploy active-duty troops domestically and fire large swaths of [purportedly] apolitical staffers,” another dispatch reveals. Several of Trump’s less conventional nominees, who hold views anathema to the bureaucracies they are poised to helm and threaten to disrupt them dramatically, have only further fueled the federal freakout. As unhinged as related stories from regime mouthpieces may seem on their face, one would be wrong to dismiss them as merely the Trump-deranged’s temper tantrum over a lost election. Rather, what these reports collectively illustrate is the hubris of unelected and unaccountable bureaucrats. They foreshadow perhaps the bloodiest coming political battle in Trump’s war to restore Americans’ control over our republic. This will require overcoming myriad entrenched forces. First and foremost among them is the administrative state wherein these bureaucrats reside — an arguably unconstitutional branch unto itself that has usurped and combined the powers of the legislative and judicial branches, defining tyranny. The hubris among those in the administrative state is that they believe they know better than We the People, and that therefore they must substitute their policy preferences for our own by any means necessary. Who we voted for then doesn’t really matter because even when we give our elected representatives a mandate, the policy predilections of the “executive” agencies in-name-only must prevail. This is the true threat to democracy, and the dangerous status quo that has prevailed for too long and exploded into public view during the first Trump administration. The second Trump administration was elected as the antidote — to make radical, not incremental, changes in personnel and policy, and make the people sovereign again. Our ruling regime’s fear that Americans would self-govern rather than remain subjects explains why the president faced impeachments, indictments, and assassination attempts, among other attacks. The Department of Justice (DOJ) led the lawfare inquisition against Trump and those in his orbit, Jan. 6 protestors, pro-lifers, practicing Catholics, and engaged parents. It has effectively criminalized dissent. A hyper-politicized and weaponized DOJ is the death knell of the rule of law and justice in this country. The Department of Defense’s politicization at its highest levels is equally disturbing. It would be bad enough if, as Trump’s nominee for Secretary of Defense, Pete Hegseth, has lamented, lowered fitness standards and an emphasis on wokeness and “diversity, equity, and inclusion” eroded the lethality of our fighting forces. But as recent reporting suggests, we also face an apparent crisis of insubordination — a breakdown in the chain of command that poses a dire threat to our security. It is an invitation for our enemies to test us. News that some at the Pentagon plan to thwart the Trump administration comes on the heels of outgoing Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin’s Pentagon-wide letter affirming that the U.S. military stands ready to “obey all lawful orders from its civilian chain of command” under the new administration. The insinuation is that unlawful orders rather than simply disfavored policies might be forthcoming, and that the military would disobey them. In fact, resistance forces have been telegraphing such efforts for months, replete with “tabletop exercises” simulating a standoff between Trump and the generals, in what journalist Lee Smith hypothesizes represents a sinister plot to divide the military. This from a defense establishment whose former senior officials, arguably in violation of their codes of conduct, if not certainly in violation of the public trust, have attacked Trump as a fascist; a defense establishment from which hails the last chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, who allegedly told Chinese counterparts he would tip them off to any coming attack and conspired with the former speaker to prevent Trump from using nuclear weapons; a defense establishment that played “shell games” to keep troops in Syria against Trump’s wishes. Resistance efforts of course are likely to span far beyond these agencies, and though they may take more “banal” forms — as a former Trump administration official recently told me — they will be no less corrosive to our republic. As James Sherk, a former top civil service reform advisor to President Trump on the White House Domestic Policy Council, has detailed, during Trump’s first term, bureaucrats across a raft of agencies commonly subverted the president’s policies through “withholding information, refusing to implement policies, intentionally delaying or slow-walking priorities, deliberately underperforming; leaking to Congress and the media; and outright insubordination.” This is precisely why Trump and his transition team have emphasized loyalty as perhaps the key criteria for those who will serve in his second administration. The media frames this in terms of bad faith, characterizing loyal staffers as toadies who will rubberstamp lawless acts. Set aside for the moment that the president has historically surrounded himself with people holding a diverse array of views — as with his initial slate of appointments this term — encouraged his personnel to debate them before him, and weighed all perspectives before making final decisions. And set aside that the Obama-Biden and Biden-Harris administrations actually engaged in the lawless and authoritarian actions that regime media dishonestly claims Trump would engage in in his second term. Loyalty means fidelity to the president’s agenda — dogged devotion to helping him execute the mandate for which we voted in the face of staunch opposition. This should be the bare minimum of what is required of personnel. It’s what every administration would expect of its staffers. It means that presidential personnel bring all of their skills and abilities to bear, provide their best possible advice, and when shots are called, do everything in their power to craft and implement policy as effectively and expeditiously as possible. What the media is implicitly saying, in referring to loyalty pejoratively, is that they want Trump to hire disloyal appointees who will sabotage, subvert, and stymie the duly elected president — to prevent the American people from getting the policies we voted for. The fear, in truth, is that if Americans get what we want, the ruling class will lose its power, prerogatives, and privileges. Every day, the incoming Trump administration will face resistance from uniparty congressmen, establishment judges, blue states, corporate media, popular cultural institutions, and beyond. But the first point of friction will always be with the Leviathan administrative state. The task for the Trump administration then will be to execute its agenda not only while the resistance challenges it in a thousand-front war, but with limited appointees, political capital, and time. Hiring cabinet and sub-cabinet officials who build teams firmly aligned with the president’s mission, comprised of those who are smart, tough, and will zealously work to fulfill the mission every day — prioritizing essential policy reforms, anticipating the ways they may be circumvented, and using every tool at their disposal to execute accordingly — is the first step towards overcoming the challenges at hand. Trump’s campaign also showed us the power of the bully pulpit — of the ability to go over the heads of all the hostile forces of propaganda and bring the message straight to the American people. That the president’s picks for vice president and cabinet have shown themselves to be compelling and charismatic speakers suggests the administration may well exploit these talents to maximum political effect. It would do well to do so. The future of our republic may rest upon these efforts.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Right  
This article exhibits a strong right-wing bias, as it portrays Donald Trump as a champion of democracy fighting against an "administrative state" it characterizes as tyrannical. The language used is highly favorable towards Trump and critical of bureaucrats and institutions that oppose him, suggesting a narrative that leans heavily on populist themes common in right-wing media. The framing of dissent against Trump as "lawfare" and the depiction of resistance within the military and government as subversion further aligns with right-wing ideologies focused on anti-establishment sentiments.
AI Classification Explanation: This article exhibits a strong right-wing bias, as it portrays Donald Trump as a champion of democracy fighting against an "administrative state" it characterizes as tyrannical. The language used is highly favorable towards Trump and critical of bureaucrats and institutions that oppose him, suggesting a narrative that leans heavily on populist themes common in right-wing media. The framing of dissent against Trump as "lawfare" and the depiction of resistance within the military and government as subversion further aligns with right-wing ideologies focused on anti-establishment sentiments.
AI Summary:
In the aftermath of Donald Trump's election victory, concerns are mounting within the federal bureaucracy, with reports indicating that officials are anxious about their positions amid the potential changes Trump may impose in his second term. This anxiety stems from the belief that Trump’s unconventional nominees could disrupt established norms within federal agencies. The article argues that the real threat to democracy lies within the administrative state, which has historically undermined the will of the voters by prioritizing bureaucratic preferences over elected officials' mandates.

Throughout his first term, Trump faced numerous challenges from the Department of Justice and Department of Defense, where politicization has led to what is described as insubordination and a compromise of military readiness. As Trump prepares for his second administration, he is urged to prioritize loyalty among his appointees to ensure effective implementation of his policies. The article asserts that bureaucrats have historically resisted and subverted presidential policies through various means, emphasizing the need for Trump to appoint staff committed to advancing his agenda amidst opposition from various entities, including Congress and the media.

The piece also highlights the importance of clear communication from the administration to the public, leveraging charismatic officials to counteract negative narratives in the media. Ultimately, the success of Trump's second term is deemed reliant on his ability to navigate the entrenched bureaucratic challenges and reassert control over the administrative state.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article presents a viewpoint that aligns with conservative perspectives, emphasizing loyalty to the president and criticizing the federal bureaucracy for obstructing his agenda. It portrays Trump’s potential nominees in a favorable light while framing the administrative state and media as adversaries to his governance. This language suggests a bias that leans toward rightist ideology, aiming to validate Trump's approach and reinforce support among his base.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article presents a viewpoint that aligns with conservative perspectives, emphasizing loyalty to the president and criticizing the federal bureaucracy for obstructing his agenda. It portrays Trump’s potential nominees in a favorable light while framing the administrative state and media as adversaries to his governance. This language suggests a bias that leans toward rightist ideology, aiming to validate Trump's approach and reinforce support among his base.

title: Dem Sen. Murphy: We Should ‘Come After Elon Musk’ He ‘Made His Fortune Off of Taxpayers’
body: On Thursday’s broadcast of MSNBC’s “Katy Tur Reports,” Sen. Chris Murphy (D-CT) questioned the effectiveness of the Department of Government Efficiency and stated that Elon Musk “basically has made his fortune off of government subsidies” and Democrats should “come after the insurance companies, the big defense companies that are all reaping huge amounts of money off of the government. Let’s come after Elon Musk, who’s made his fortune off of taxpayers.” Murphy said, “I’m just not sure that [DOGE] has anything to do with breaking up the status quo. You’ve put a billionaire, who basically has made his fortune off of government subsidies in charge of deciding how the government should spend its money. This sounds like either a con job, in which Elon Musk comes out of this with his programs protected, and perhaps his competitors’ programs targeted or just a TV show. … So, yes, I think Democrats should put on the table how we think we can cut government. Let’s come after the drug companies, come after the insurance companies, the big defense companies that are all reaping huge amounts of money off of the government. Let’s come after Elon Musk, who’s made his fortune off of taxpayers. Democrats should be involved in the conversation about government efficiency. I just don’t know that this group has anything to do with actual, meaningful commonsense cuts. It may be about protecting billionaires from those cuts or it may just be about a publicity stunt.” Follow Ian Hanchett on Twitter @IanHanchett

Left  
The article primarily presents a viewpoint aligned with the Democratic party, specifically by highlighting criticism against Elon Musk and government subsidies in a way that reflects a progressive stance. It emphasizes government intervention and the need for accountability from billionaires, which aligns with leftist ideologies. The choice of platform, MSNBC, which is known to lean left, further indicates the overall bias in the article’s perspective.

The choice of platform, MSNBC, which is known to lean left, further indicates the overall bias in the article’s perspective.

Murphy emphasized the necessity for Democrats to engage in discussions about reducing government expenditure, while questioning the true intent behind recent government efficiency initiatives.

title: Stowaway who flew from New York to Paris returns to NYC to face charges
body: NEW YORK -- The woman accused of sneaking onto a Delta Air Lines flight from New York City to Paris last week returned to John F. Kennedy International Airport on Wednesday. The suspect, identified as Svetlana Dali, a 57-year-old Russian National, boarded a Delta flight to return to New York from Charles de Gaulle Airport in Paris, after a previous attempt was derailed by an outburst. She was escorted by French law enforcement and U.S. Customs and Border Patrol agents. The plane was greeted by police when it landed. Dali was later arrested by the FBI and was expected to spend the night in jail before making an appearance at U.S. District Court in Brooklyn on Thursday, the bureau said. Dali, who lives in Philadelphia, is accused of sneaking past airport security and boarding a Delta flight to Paris on Nov. 26 without a boarding pass. The Transportation Security Administration confirmed it reviewed security footage showing Dali using a TSA lane for known crew members. That lane eventually merges with the general public, at which point Dali is seen mingling with a group of people getting their IDs checked before slipping by. She did go through a body scanner, and her bag was flagged during screening for having two bottles of water, which she discarded. Dali was discovered as a stowaway while the plane was still in midair and was taken into custody when she landed in Paris and refused entry to France. In a statement, the TSA downplayed the security breach, saying, "This is the only reported case of unauthorized access when over 18 million passengers were screened at TSA security checkpoints during the busiest Thanksgiving travel season ever." The TSA said it has opened a civil case against her. "Delta would like to thank French and U.S. authorities for their assistance in this matter," Delta Air Lines said in a statement. "Our review affirms that Delta's security infrastructure, as part of our Safety Management System framework, is sound and that deviation from standard procedures is the root cause of this event. We are thoroughly addressing this matter and will continue to work closely with our regulators, law enforcement and other relevant stakeholders. Nothing is of greater importance than safety and security." CBS News confirmed Dali created a disruption on her return flight Saturday when authorities initially attempted to take her to the States. She was removed from that flight by French law enforcement, causing a delay of more than two hours. Kris Van Cleave and Pat Milton contributed to this report.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Center  
This article reports on a specific incident involving a stowaway without displaying evident bias toward any political perspective. It focuses on the facts of the case, including details about security protocols and law enforcement involvement, while quoting relevant authorities. The tone is neutral and informative, appropriate for a center-leaning news article. There are no ideological leanings or emotionally charged language present, which further supports its classification as center.
AI Classification Explanation: This article reports on a specific incident involving a stowaway without displaying evident bias toward any political perspective. It focuses on the facts of the case, including details about security protocols and law enforcement involvement, while quoting relevant authorities. The tone is neutral and informative, appropriate for a center-leaning news article. There are no ideological leanings or emotionally charged language present, which further supports its classification as center.
AI Summary:
A 57-year-old Russian woman named Svetlana Dali returned to John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York after sneaking onto a Delta Air Lines flight to Paris on November 26 without a boarding pass. She was escorted back by French law enforcement and U.S. Customs and Border Patrol agents, and was arrested by the FBI upon landing. Dali was expected to face a court appearance in Brooklyn following her arrest. 

The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) reported that Dali breached security by using a lane designated for known crew members, where she mixed with other passengers before boarding. Although she set off a warning during screening for carrying two bottles of water, they were discarded. Authorities discovered her as a stowaway while in midair and upon landing in Paris, she was denied entry into France. 

The TSA stated that this was the only case of unauthorized access during a busy Thanksgiving travel period. Delta Air Lines confirmed its security protocols are sound and thanked authorities for their assistance. Dali had previously caused disruption when attempts were made to return her to the U.S. on another flight.

Center
