title: Biden White House eyeing preemptive pardons to protect people from Trump
body: President Biden and his top aides are tinkering with the idea of issuing preemptive pardons to individuals they fear will be targeted by President-elect Donald Trump when he takes office. There is a running list of potential pardon recipients, senior Democrats familiar with the plans told Politico, a news website in Washington. One includes former GOP Rep. Liz Cheney of Wyoming, who was a member of the Jan. 6 committee that looked into the Capitol riot. She has been an outspoken critic of Mr. Trump and lost reelection in 2022 to a Trump-backed Republican candidate. She also backed Vice President Kamala Harris in this election cycle, as did her father, former Vice President Dick Cheney. Another Jan. 6 committee member on the list is Sen.-elect Adam B. Schiff, California Democrat. The committee’s final report recommended criminal charges against Mr. Trump. Anthony Fauci, who led the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases during the COVID-19 pandemic, is also on the list. He received a lot of criticism from the right over his handling of the pandemic and rejection of the theory that the virus leaked from a lab in China, which is now widely accepted. Retired Joint Chiefs of Staff Chairman Gen. Mark A. Milley is also named, a source told ABC News. Gen. Milley, who held his position from 2019 to 2023, started to speak out against Mr. Trump during this election cycle, and in journalist Bob Woodward’s book, he called the president-elect a “fascist to the core.” He was also criticized by Republicans over the withdrawal of troops from Afghanistan. The considerations come after Mr. Biden announced a full pardon for his son Hunter Biden earlier this week. Hunter Biden’s pardon covers 11 years of any crimes he committed. The pardon received backlash from Republicans and Democrats, but Mr. Biden said he did it because “in trying to break Hunter, they’ve tried to break me — and there’s no reason to believe it will stop here.” Mr. Biden and his aides aren’t the only ones who have thought this may be necessary. Rep. Brendan Boyle, Pennsylvania Democrat, called for Mr. Biden to issue blanket pardons. “This is no hypothetical threat,” Mr. Boyle said in a statement Wednesday. “The people they’re targeting include law enforcement officers, military personnel, and others who have spent their lives protecting this country. These patriots shouldn’t have to live in fear of political retribution for doing what’s right. That’s why I’m urging President Biden to issue a blanket pardon for anyone unjustly targeted by this vindictive scheme.” “The time for cautious restraint is over,” he said. “We must act with urgency to push back against these threats and prevent Trump from abusing his power.” Mr. Trump has many times railed against his political enemies and the “deep state,” and he has made suggestive comments about going after them.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article primarily focuses on the Biden administration's considerations regarding preemptive pardons in the context of potential political retaliation by Donald Trump. It highlights democratic figures and their criticism of Trump, portraying a sense of urgency and concern among Democrats. The emphasis on Biden's actions and the support of Democratic representatives indicates a bias towards the left, as it implicitly critiques the Republican stance and amplifies the narrative surrounding Trump as a threat. While it may not be overtly partisan, its overall tone aligns more with lean left perspectives.
AI Classification Explanation: The article primarily focuses on the Biden administration's considerations regarding preemptive pardons in the context of potential political retaliation by Donald Trump. It highlights democratic figures and their criticism of Trump, portraying a sense of urgency and concern among Democrats. The emphasis on Biden's actions and the support of Democratic representatives indicates a bias towards the left, as it implicitly critiques the Republican stance and amplifies the narrative surrounding Trump as a threat. While it may not be overtly partisan, its overall tone aligns more with lean left perspectives.
AI Summary: The Biden administration is considering issuing preemptive pardons for individuals they believe may be targeted by President-elect Donald Trump. A source reported there is a list of potential recipients, including former GOP Rep. Liz Cheney, who was a vocal critic of Trump and served on the Jan. 6 committee. Other names include Sen.-elect Adam B. Schiff and Anthony Fauci, who faced criticism regarding his handling of the pandemic, as well as retired Gen. Mark A. Milley, who publicly opposed Trump and commented on his leadership style. This discussion follows Biden's recent pardon of his son, Hunter Biden, which he justified as a protective measure amidst political attacks. Democratic Rep. Brendan Boyle has also called for blanket pardons to shield individuals from potential political retribution, emphasizing the need for urgent action against perceived threats from Trump.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article showcases a perspective that aligns with Democratic priorities, focusing on potential pardons influenced by political dynamics. It highlights figures who have publicly opposed Trump, suggesting a protective lens around individuals critical of the former president. Additionally, references to Hunter Biden's pardon and calls from a Democratic representative for blanket pardons emphasize a narrative concerned with political retribution, which typically resonates with a left-leaning audience.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article showcases a perspective that aligns with Democratic priorities, focusing on potential pardons influenced by political dynamics. It highlights figures who have publicly opposed Trump, suggesting a protective lens around individuals critical of the former president. Additionally, references to Hunter Biden's pardon and calls from a Democratic representative for blanket pardons emphasize a narrative concerned with political retribution, which typically resonates with a left-leaning audience.

title: Jan. 6 Defendant Gets Reduced Prison Sentence
body: A Texas man who was the first protester to go on trial for the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the U.S. Capitol was resentenced on Friday to nearly seven years in prison after he delivered an angry, profane rant to the judge who agreed to modestly reduce his original sentence. Guy Reffitt benefitted from a U.S. Supreme Court ruling that led to the dismissal of his conviction on an obstruction charge. His new sentence — six years and eight months — is seven months lower than his original sentence. Reffitt repeatedly shook his head and appeared to be agitated as he listened to U.S. District Judge Dabney Friedrich and a prosecutor describe his role in a mob's attack on the Capitol. He told the judge that he was "in my feelings" and upset about the "lies and the craziness" that he perceived. "I was not there to take over no government," Reffitt said. "I love this country." "No one has a problem with your feelings," the judge said. "It's the actions you took with your feelings." Reffitt stormed the Captiol with a holstered handgun on his waist. He also was carrying zip-tie handcuffs and wearing body armor and a helmet equipped with a video camera when he advanced on police officers outside the building. He retreated after an officer pepper sprayed him in the face, but he waved on other rioters who ultimately breached the building. Prosecutors said Reffitt told fellow members of the Texas Three Percenters militia group that he planned to drag House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif., out of the Capitol building by her ankles, "with her head hitting every step on the way down." "His objective was to overtake Congress, physically and with violence," said Assistant U.S. Attorney Jeffrey Nestler. "In his own words," Nestler added, "Congress was the demon and he was going to cut the head off the demon." Reffitt is one of several Jan. 6 defendants to be resentenced after a Supreme Court ruling in June limited the government's use of a federal obstruction law. The high court ruled 6-3 that a charge of obstructing an official proceeding must include proof that a defendant tried to tamper with or destroy documents — a distinction that applies to few Jan. 6 criminal cases. A jury convicted Reffitt of four other counts, including a charge that he threatened his two teenage children after returning to their in home in Wylie, Texas, after the attack. Reffitt’s son Jackson, then 19, testified that his father told him and his younger sister, then 16, that they would be traitors if they reported him to authorities and warned them that "traitors get shot." Reffitt's two daughters spoke favorably of their father during his resentencing. They described him as a caring father who doesn't pose a danger to anybody. Prosecutors said Reffitt’s recent communications from jail indicate that he "views his imprisonment as an injustice and as part of a greater cause, and that he maintains pride in actions on January 6 and his involvement in the community of those who he believes have been wrongly prosecuted for their crimes on that day." More than 1,500 people have been charged with Capitol attack-related crimes. About 1,000 of them have pleaded guilty. Roughly 250 others have been convicted by a judge or jury after a trial.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Center  
The article presents factual details surrounding Guy Reffitt's sentencing regarding the January 6 Capitol attack, including quotes from the judge, prosecutors, and Reffitt himself. It does not exhibit strong language or emotionally charged rhetoric commonly associated with partisan perspectives. By focusing on the legal proceedings and outcomes without promoting a specific agenda, the article maintains a neutral tone, characteristic of center bias in media.
AI Classification Explanation: The article presents factual details surrounding Guy Reffitt's sentencing regarding the January 6 Capitol attack, including quotes from the judge, prosecutors, and Reffitt himself. It does not exhibit strong language or emotionally charged rhetoric commonly associated with partisan perspectives. By focusing on the legal proceedings and outcomes without promoting a specific agenda, the article maintains a neutral tone, characteristic of center bias in media.
AI Summary:
A Texas man, Guy Reffitt, who was the first protester to face trial for the Jan. 6, 2021, Capitol attack, has received a reduced prison sentence of nearly seven years following a resentencing hearing. This reduction came after a U.S. Supreme Court ruling led to the dismissal of a conviction for obstruction of an official proceeding. Reffitt now faces six years and eight months, which is seven months less than his original sentence. During the resentencing, Reffitt expressed agitation and frustration with the proceedings, claiming he was not intent on overthrowing the government and asserting his love for the country. However, the judge highlighted that his actions spoke louder than his feelings.

Reffitt was armed with a handgun, zip-tie handcuffs, body armor, and a helmet with a camera during the attack, and he led other rioters toward the Capitol after being temporarily repelled by police. Prosecutors emphasized his violent intentions, including threats made against House Speaker Nancy Pelosi. Following the Supreme Court ruling, several other defendants in similar cases have also been resentenced. Reffitt has been convicted on multiple counts, including threatening his own children to keep silent about his actions. His daughters defended him during the resentencing, asserting that he is a caring father. Currently, over 1,500 individuals have been charged in connection with the Capitol riot, with many pleading guilty or being convicted after trials.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
This article presents a critical view of Guy Reffitt’s actions during the Capitol attack, underscoring the severity of his behavior and consistent framing of his violent intentions. The mention of legal proceedings emphasizes accountability, which aligns more with a left-leaning perspective that typically advocates for justice and accountability regarding issues of insurrection and violence. Furthermore, the portrayal of his actions juxtaposed with the defense from his daughters hints at a perspective focused on moral judgment rather than neutrality, suggesting a lean towards the left.

The mention of legal proceedings emphasizes accountability, which aligns more with a left-leaning perspective that typically advocates for justice and accountability regarding issues of insurrection and violence. Furthermore, the portrayal of his actions juxtaposed with the defense from his daughters hints at a perspective focused on moral judgment rather than neutrality, suggesting a lean towards the left.

title: Breaking Down Donald Trump’s Call for ‘Energy Dominance’ and Its Potential Real-World Limits
body: WASHINGTON — President-elect Donald Trump is set to create a National Energy Council that he says will establish American “energy dominance” around the world as he seeks to boost U.S. oil and gas drilling and move away from President Joe Biden’s focus on climate change. The energy council — to be led by North Dakota Gov. Doug Burgum, Trump’s choice to head the Interior Department — will be key in Trump’s pledge to “drill, drill, drill" and sell more oil and other energy sources to allies in Europe and around the globe. The new council will be granted sweeping authority over federal agencies involved in energy permitting, production, generation, distribution, regulation and transportation, with a mandate to cut bureaucratic red tape, enhance private sector investments and focus on innovation instead of “totally unnecessary regulation,” Trump said. But Trump's energy wishes are likely to run into real-world limits. For one, U.S. oil production under Biden is already at record levels. The federal government cannot force companies to drill for more oil, and production increases could lower prices and reduce profits. A call for energy dominance — a term Trump also used in his first term as president — "is an opportunity, not a requirement,'' for the oil industry to move forward on drilling projects under terms that are likely to be more favorable to industry than those offered by Biden, said energy analyst Kevin Book. Whether Trump achieves energy dominance — however he defines it — "comes down to decisions by private companies, based on how they see supply-demand balances in the global marketplace,'' said Book, managing partner at ClearView Energy Partners, a Washington research firm. Don't expect an immediate influx of new oil rigs dotting the national landscape, he said. Trump's bid to boost oil supplies — and lower U.S. prices — is complicated by his threat this week to impose 25% import tariffs on Canada and Mexico, two of the largest sources of U.S. oil imports. The U.S. oil industry warned the tariffs could raise prices and even harm national security. “Canada and Mexico are our top energy trading partners, and maintaining the free flow of energy products across our borders is critical for North American energy security and U.S. consumers,” said Scott Lauermann, speaking for the American Petroleum Institute, the oil industry’s top lobbying group. American Fuel & Petrochemical Manufacturers, which represents U.S. refineries, also opposes potential tariffs, saying in a statement that “American refiners depend on crude oil from Canada and Mexico to produce the affordable, reliable fuels consumers count on every day." Energy lobbyist Scott Segal said the idea of centering energy decisions at the White House follows an example set by Biden, who named a trio of White House advisers to lead on climate policy. Segal, a partner at the law and policy law firm Bracewell, called Burgum “a steady hand on the tiller” with experience in fossil fuels and renewables. And unlike Biden’s climate advisers — Gina McCarthy, John Podesta and Ali Zaidi — Burgum will probably take his White House post as a Senate-confirmed Cabinet member, Segal said. Dustin Meyer, senior vice president of policy, economics and regulatory affairs at the American Petroleum Institute, called the new energy council “a good thing” for the U.S. economy and trade. “Conceptually it makes a lot of sense to have as much coordination as possible,” he said. Still, “market dynamics will always be the key'' for any potential increase in energy production, Meyer said. Jonathan Elkind, a senior research scholar at Columbia University’s Center on Global Energy Policy, called energy dominance a “deliberately vague concept,” but said, “It's hard to see how (Trump) can push more oil into an already saturated market." Trump has promised to bring gasoline prices below $2 a gallon, but experts call that highly unlikely, since crude oil prices would need to drop dramatically to achieve that goal. Gas prices averaged $3.06 nationally as of Friday, down from $3.25 a year ago, according to AAA. Elkind and other experts said they hope the new energy council will move beyond oil to focus on renewable energy such as wind, solar and geothermal power, as well as nuclear. None of those energy resources produces greenhouse gas emissions that contribute to climate change. "Failure to focus on climate change as an existential threat to our planet is a huge concern and translates to a very significant loss of American property and American lives,'' said Elkind, a former assistant energy secretary in the Obama administration. He cited federal statistics showing two dozen weather disasters this year that caused more than $1 billion in damage each. A total of 418 people were killed. Trump has played down risks from climate change and pledged to rescind unspent money in the Inflation Reduction Act, Biden’s landmark climate and health care bill. He also said he will stop offshore wind development when he returns to the White House in January. Even so, his Nov. 15 announcement of the energy council says he will “expand ALL forms of energy production to grow our Economy and create good-paying jobs.” That includes renewables, said Safak Yucel, associate professor at Georgetown University’s McDonough School of Business. "The mandate for the energy council is U.S. dominance globally, but what's more American than American solar and American wind?'' he asked. A report from Ernst & Young last year showed that solar was the cheapest source of new-build electricity in many markets. Trump, in his statement, said he wants to dramatically increase baseload power to lower electricity costs, avoid brownouts and “WIN the battle for AI superiority." In comments to reporters before he was named to the energy post, Burgum cited a similar goal, noting increased demand for electricity from artificial intelligence, commonly known as AI, and fast-growing data centers. “The AI battle affects everything from defense to health care to education to productivity as a country,″ Burgum said. While Trump mocks the climate law as the “green new scam,” he is unlikely to repeal it, Yucel and other experts said. One reason: Most of its investments and jobs are in Republican congressional districts. GOP members of Congress have urged House Speaker Mike Johnson to retain the law, which passed with only Democratic votes. “A lot of Southern states are telling Trump, ‘We actually like renewables,'" Yucel said, noting that Republican-led states have added thousands of jobs in recent years in wind, solar and battery power. If renewables make economic economic sense, he added, "they'll continue.''
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article offers a critical perspective on former President Trump's energy policies and positions, particularly in relation to renewable energy and climate change, suggesting skepticism about his plans for "energy dominance." It highlights potential limitations to Trump's proposed actions and includes viewpoints from experts emphasizing the importance of addressing climate change, which tends to align with more progressive environmental stances. Additionally, the inclusion of quotes from those criticizing Trump’s administration indicates a critical lens towards right-leaning energy policies, suggesting a lean towards left-leaning media bias.
AI Classification Explanation: The article offers a critical perspective on former President Trump's energy policies and positions, particularly in relation to renewable energy and climate change, suggesting skepticism about his plans for "energy dominance." It highlights potential limitations to Trump's proposed actions and includes viewpoints from experts emphasizing the importance of addressing climate change, which tends to align with more progressive environmental stances. Additionally, the inclusion of quotes from those criticizing Trump’s administration indicates a critical lens towards right-leaning energy policies, suggesting a lean towards left-leaning media bias.
AI Summary:
In this article, President-elect Donald Trump plans to create a National Energy Council to promote American "energy dominance," focusing on increasing U.S. oil and gas drilling while moving away from President Joe Biden's climate change agenda. The council, led by North Dakota Governor Doug Burgum, will have authority over various federal energy agencies, aiming to increase private investment and streamline energy regulations. However, Trump's ambitions may face obstacles, such as already high U.S. oil production levels and potential declines in profitability due to overproduction.

Trump's proposed energy policies, including imposing tariffs on Canada and Mexico (the U.S.'s top oil suppliers), could raise energy prices and negatively impact national security, as warned by industry representatives. Although Trump's plan emphasizes the need for a White House-centered approach to energy, market dynamics will ultimately dictate production levels.

Experts predict it will be challenging for Trump to significantly increase oil supplies in an already saturated market and question the feasibility of his goal to lower gasoline prices below $2. While he has promised to support all forms of energy production, including renewables, experts highlight the need for a balanced approach that considers climate change as a pressing issue. Some analysts suggest that if renewables remain economically viable, they will continue to grow, regardless of political shifts.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Center  
This article presents a balanced view on President-elect Trump's energy policies, outlining both his intentions to push for increased oil and gas production and the potential challenges and criticisms he may face. It incorporates perspectives from industry representatives and experts, indicating that while Trump aims for "energy dominance," considerations around market dynamics and climate change must also be acknowledged. The article does not favor either side of the political spectrum, focusing instead on the implications of proposed policies in a straightforward manner.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: This article presents a balanced view on President-elect Trump's energy policies, outlining both his intentions to push for increased oil and gas production and the potential challenges and criticisms he may face. It incorporates perspectives from industry representatives and experts, indicating that while Trump aims for "energy dominance," considerations around market dynamics and climate change must also be acknowledged. The article does not favor either side of the political spectrum, focusing instead on the implications of proposed policies in a straightforward manner.

title: Congressional Panel Concludes Covid Likely Came from Wuhan Lab
body: The congressional panel tasked with investigating the Covid-19 pandemic concluded in a report released Monday that the virus most likely originated from a lab leak in Wuhan, China. The House Select Subcommittee on the Coronavirus Pandemic’s 500-page final report details its two-year investigation into the pandemic’s origins and the government response. “The COVID-19 pandemic highlighted a distrust in leadership. Trust is earned. Accountability, transparency, honesty, and integrity will regain this trust. A future pandemic requires a whole of America response managed by those without personal benefit or bias. We can always do better, and for the sake of future generations of Americans, we must. It can be done,” said Representative Brad Wenstrup (R., Ohio), chairman of the subcommittee. The Covid panel determined that the pandemic probably originated in a lab because of the virus’s biological characteristics, particularly the speed with which it infected humans, and the Chinese Communist Party’s efforts to obstruct investigations into the virus’s origins. Furthermore, the Wuhan Institute of Virology, the lab in Wuhan, China, conducted risky coronavirus experiments at low safety levels and had researchers come down with a virus similar to Covid-19 months before the pandemic began. At the start of the pandemic, National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases director Dr. Anthony Fauci orchestrated the “proximal origin” paper published in Nature to discredit early proponents of the lab-leak theory. The paper was published in March 2020 after Fauci and several co-authors of the paper had discussions about the plausibility of a lab leak and the purpose of the “proximal origin” paper. In large part because of the paper, social-media platforms censored content related to the lab-leak and the theory was entirely dismissed in mainstream media as the pandemic spread around the world. Fauci and then-National Institutes of Health director Dr. Francis Collins, another top official involved in the “proximal origin” paper, later testified to the subcommittee that the lab leak is not a conspiracy theory. To compile the report, the covid subcommittee reviewed one million pages of documents and held dozens of hearings and transcribed interviews with witnesses. It marks the most sweeping investigation into the pandemic to date and the negative long-term impacts of the measures public-health officials used to attempt to slow down the disease’s spread. The subcommittee also discovered that the Justice Department empaneled a grand jury to investigate Covid-19 origins and it appears to have involved EcoHealth Alliance, the nonprofit responsible for overseeing risky, taxpayer funded coronavirus research in the Wuhan lab. The Justice Department declined to comment. EcoHealth Alliance did not respond to a request for comment. EcoHealth Alliance and its president Dr. Peter Daszak featured prominently in the subcommittee report because of the organization’s malfeasance surrounding the gain-of-function experiments it facilitated at the Wuhan Institute of Virology. EcoHealth’s failures include the gain-of-function experiments, submitting a progress report two years late, failing to report a dangerous experiment, and misleading NIH on the locations of samples, according to the subcommittee report. The subcommittee also accuses EcoHealth president Dr. Peter Daszak of obstruction, making false statements to Congress, and receiving internal NIH information from NIAID senior official Dr. David Morens, who used his private email to communicate with Daszak. Additionally, Morens helped Daszak avoid National Institutes of Health oversight of his research grant and edited letters Daszak sent to the NIH. Daszak has strenuously denied that EcoHealth facilitated gain-of-function research and dismissed concerns about its apparent lack of transparency about the experiments at the Wuhan lab. Morens seems to have evaded federal records laws by using his personal email account and received assistance from a NIH freedom of information act (FOIA) official in doing so. The FOIA official invoked her Fifth Amendment rights when the subcommittee compelled her to testify. The subcommittee determined that Morens appears to have made false statements to the subcommittee about the actions he took to evade FOIA requests and his deletion of emails from his government account. Morens also falsely told the subcommittee that he did not assist Daszak with communications to NIH and falsely claimed he only had two email accounts, his work email and personal Gmail, according to the subcommittee report. Many of the details of EcoHealth’s actions were previously publicized by the subcommittee in letters and hearings, resulting in the U.S. government initiating debarment proceedings against the organization and Daszak himself. EcoHealth and Daszak are currently suspended from receiving taxpayer funds, a status that could become permanent when the debarment proceedings are finalized. Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article presents a highly critical view of the origins of COVID-19, emphasizing the lab leak theory and government accountability while focusing on failures of specific individuals like Dr. Fauci and EcoHealth Alliance. This framing aligns with a lean right perspective, as it portrays government officials in a negative light and suggests mismanagement and undue influence in public health responses. Moreover, the article showcases a distrust in leadership, which is often a narrative prevalent in right-leaning media. The language used suggests an inclination toward conservative viewpoints on government accountability and transparency.
AI Classification Explanation: The article presents a highly critical view of the origins of COVID-19, emphasizing the lab leak theory and government accountability while focusing on failures of specific individuals like Dr. Fauci and EcoHealth Alliance. This framing aligns with a lean right perspective, as it portrays government officials in a negative light and suggests mismanagement and undue influence in public health responses. Moreover, the article showcases a distrust in leadership, which is often a narrative prevalent in right-leaning media. The language used suggests an inclination toward conservative viewpoints on government accountability and transparency.
AI Summary:
The congressional panel investigating the Covid-19 pandemic concluded that the virus likely originated from a lab leak in Wuhan, China, according to a report released on Monday. The House Select Subcommittee on the Coronavirus Pandemic's 500-page report, which summarizes a two-year investigation, cites the virus's biological characteristics and obstruction by the Chinese Communist Party as significant factors. It revealed that the Wuhan Institute of Virology conducted risky coronavirus experiments and had personnel exhibit symptoms similar to Covid-19 prior to the pandemic.

The report highlights Dr. Anthony Fauci’s role in producing a paper intended to discredit lab-leak theory advocates, which led to censorship in social media and dismissal in mainstream media. The subcommittee reviewed extensive documentation, including one million pages of evidence, and held numerous hearings. 

The findings also reveal that the Justice Department is investigating Covid-19’s origins, focusing on the EcoHealth Alliance, which oversaw controversial research at the Wuhan lab. The report criticizes EcoHealth president Dr. Peter Daszak for obstruction and mismanagement of research, noting a lack of transparency about gain-of-function experiments. Daszak denies these allegations, while the subcommittee suggests Dr. David Morens of NIAID may have aided Daszak in circumventing oversight. Currently, EcoHealth and Daszak are suspended from receiving federal funds, with potential debarment pending.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
This article leans right due to its critical tone towards prominent figures like Dr. Anthony Fauci and the Chinese Communist Party while emphasizing alleged risks and obstructions associated with EcoHealth Alliance. The focus on a lab leak theory suggests a skepticism about the establishment narrative regarding the origins of the Covid-19 virus and highlights perceived inadequacies in oversight and transparency. Additionally, the detailed criticism of specific individuals associated with the research captures a tone that may be more pronounced in right-leaning media outlets.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: This article leans right due to its critical tone towards prominent figures like Dr. Anthony Fauci and the Chinese Communist Party while emphasizing alleged risks and obstructions associated with EcoHealth Alliance. The focus on a lab leak theory suggests a skepticism about the establishment narrative regarding the origins of the Covid-19 virus and highlights perceived inadequacies in oversight and transparency. Additionally, the detailed criticism of specific individuals associated with the research captures a tone that may be more pronounced in right-leaning media outlets.

title: Meghan Trainor: I ‘Got Too Much Botox’ And A ‘Lip Flip,’ Can’t ‘Smile Anymore’
body: Pop singer Meghan Trainor said she regrets a cosmetic procedure she had recently which has left her unable to smile properly.The 30-year-old star discussed what happened during a recent episode of her “Workin’ On It” podcast, admitting she “got too much Botox.”“I messed up,” she added.“Someone convinced me with my little lips that if you did a lip flip, you put filler right above your upper lip, that you could have a beautiful flip on your upper lip. And I could have one for the first time in my whole 30 years of living — it was not true,” she said.“I cannot smile anymore,” Trainor went on. “Everywhere I go, I cannot smile. My face hurts to smile, to even try.”AdvertisementTrainor demonstrated her new look, saying, “This is as big as I can smile,” while addressing the camera.She then shared a photo of herself holding a dog at a shelter. She said she was a “happy person” in the photo even if she didn’t look like it. “I look like I smelled someone’s fart,” she joked while speaking with her brother on the podcast. View this post on Instagram A post shared by Workin’ On It Podcast (@workinonitpod)AdvertisementThe singer told her followers, “Don’t try everything.”The “Whoops” singer said despite the cosmetic procedure fail, she’s still planning on getting a breast procedure in the future.AdvertisementCHECK OUT THE DAILY WIRE HOLIDAY GIFT GUIDETrainor said she wants to get “just a little lift,” and “maybe a little implant just so they’re like, ‘We are boobs,’ ‘cause right now, they are not.”According to the American Society of Plastic Surgeons, a lip flip uses Botox “to relax a muscle in the upper lip, causing the lip to ‘flip’ and giving the appearance of a fuller upper lip. The procedure is different than getting lip fillers, which are injections directly into the lip, as opposed to above it.”The procedure is said to look more “natural” than traditional fillers.Several celebrities have been forthcoming about their plastic surgery failures in the past. Last year, “Little House on the Prairie” actress Melissa Gilbert said she underwent cosmetic surgery that made her look like “the spawn of Satan.”“I had no facial expression, which is anathema considering what I do for a living,” Gilbert said at the time, adding, “It’s exhausting keeping up that kind of façade. I was very insecure.”Advertisement
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Center  
The article reports on Meghan Trainor's unfortunate experience with cosmetic procedures, presenting her story in a straightforward manner without strong opinions or emotional language. It provides facts, quotes, and insights into the procedures while including a balance of humor and seriousness. There is no overt political bias, making it a neutral account focusing on a celebrity's personal experience rather than pushing a particular ideological viewpoint.
AI Classification Explanation: The article reports on Meghan Trainor's unfortunate experience with cosmetic procedures, presenting her story in a straightforward manner without strong opinions or emotional language. It provides facts, quotes, and insights into the procedures while including a balance of humor and seriousness. There is no overt political bias, making it a neutral account focusing on a celebrity's personal experience rather than pushing a particular ideological viewpoint.
AI Summary: Meghan Trainor recently revealed her regrets about a cosmetic procedure, specifically a lip flip and too much Botox, that left her unable to smile properly. Speaking on her “Workin’ On It” podcast, the 30-year-old singer described the procedure as a mistake, saying she had been convinced it would enhance her lips but instead hindered her ability to smile, causing her facial discomfort. Although she shared a photo depicting her as a “happy person,” she humorously remarked about her expression, implying she looked displeased. Despite her experience with the lip flip, Trainor expressed intentions to undergo a breast procedure in the future, which she hopes will give her a more appealing appearance. The lip flip, which involves the use of Botox to relax the muscles above the lip for a fuller look, differs from traditional lip fillers. Other celebrities have shared their own stories of cosmetic surgery mishaps, highlighting the risks associated with such procedures.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Center  
The article presents a straightforward account of Meghan Trainor's experiences with cosmetic procedures without expressing a particular political stance or ideology. It objectively discusses her regrets and future plans, focusing on personal choice rather than cultural or social commentary, making it a neutral piece suitable for general readership. The inclusion of other celebrities’ experiences adds to the informative nature without leaning toward any particular bias.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article presents a straightforward account of Meghan Trainor's experiences with cosmetic procedures without expressing a particular political stance or ideology. It objectively discusses her regrets and future plans, focusing on personal choice rather than cultural or social commentary, making it a neutral piece suitable for general readership. The inclusion of other celebrities’ experiences adds to the informative nature without leaning toward any particular bias.

title: How a French Whale Made $85 Million off Trump’s Win
body: On October 15, three weeks before the presidential election, Ashley Grosse heard that a Frenchman wanted to run a study with the firm where she works, YouGov. In an email, the prospective client told the firm he wanted to poll “the current U.S. elections focused on three swing states, specifically Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin,” investigating the “shy voter effects” within the next seven days. “The faster, the better,” he wrote.Soon Grosse, the general manager for YouGov’s Scientific Research unit, found herself in a Zoom meeting with the Frenchman, where she agreed to conduct the polling he wanted. What she went on to discover with her poll led him to place the single largest bet ever made on an election. His wager was that Donald Trump would win—and win big.“I had conviction,” the high-rolling whale told me over the phone last week, “so I bet a lot of money.”That a trader living in Europe was able to predict such a decisive victory when every major professional pollster was forecasting a dead heat is one of the most surprising tales of the U.S. election. Now, the Frenchman is revealing to The Free Press exclusive details about how he did it.In our conversations by phone and email, I discovered he is a trader who wanted to go by the pseudonym “Théo,” because he said disclosing his identity “would disrupt my life, as my family and friends are not aware of the extent of my wealth. It will also seriously endanger my safety and that of my kids.”Back in October, Grosse—who knows Théo’s true identity—told him it was extremely difficult to gauge the preferences of so-called “shy voters,” who either can’t be reached or refuse to talk to pollsters. But Théo said he had an idea. He had seen some academic literature about “social circle polling,” in which pollsters asked people not only who they were voting for but who they thought their acquaintances were voting for. Those polls had performed well. He wanted Grosse’s team to do something similar: Ask people in the three swing states who they thought their neighbors were planning to vote for. Grosse later told me she found his idea “intellectually interesting,” but she was skeptical the neighbor question would unearth anything useful. But Théo was convinced it would smoke out a major preference for Trump over Kamala Harris that was hiding in plain sight. “It was clear to me that most of the polls were skewed to the advantage of Harris by. . . ignoring the shy Trump voter effect,” he wrote to me in an email.What Grosse didn’t know—what nobody knew at the time—was the reason he was commissioning the poll: He was placing multimillion-dollar bets with Polymarket, the popular prediction market. Even before engaging YouGov, he had wagered $30 million on Trump. Once he saw the results of the neighbor question at the end of October, he went all in, using 11 different crypto accounts to raise his stake to $80 million. In fact, he was so confident Trump would win, he told me he sold off virtually all his liquid assets to raise the $80 million for his wager. This post is for paying subscribers only Subscribe now Already have an account? Sign in
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article discusses a trader’s successful betting strategy on Donald Trump's election victory and touches on "shy voters," suggesting a favorable view towards Trump's supporters. The focus on how a European's insights led to a major financial win for betting on Trump aligns more with viewpoints typically found in lean right media. The use of financial success tied to Trump's win, rather than criticism of his candidacy, further contributes to this classification.
AI Classification Explanation: The article discusses a trader’s successful betting strategy on Donald Trump's election victory and touches on "shy voters," suggesting a favorable view towards Trump's supporters. The focus on how a European's insights led to a major financial win for betting on Trump aligns more with viewpoints typically found in lean right media. The use of financial success tied to Trump's win, rather than criticism of his candidacy, further contributes to this classification.
AI Summary:
In October 2020, Ashley Grosse from YouGov was approached by a French trader, pseudonymously known as "Théo," to conduct a poll focused on the U.S. presidential election, particularly in swing states Pennsylvania, Michigan, and Wisconsin. Théo sought to explore the "shy voter effect" by using a unique polling method known as "social circle polling," where respondents would predict their neighbors' voting preferences. Despite initial skepticism from Grosse regarding the potential value of this approach, Théo was confident it would reveal a significant preference for Donald Trump that mainstream polls were missing.

Théo had already placed substantial bets, totaling $30 million on Trump’s victory before commissioning the YouGov poll. After seeing results that aligned with his expectations, he increased his wager significantly to $80 million, utilizing multiple crypto accounts to do so. He even liquidated most of his assets to fund this bet. Théo’s successful prediction and large wager provided a surprising contrast to prevailing polling forecasts that indicated a closer race.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
This article discusses a method to gauge voter sentiment that seems to favor Donald Trump, which suggests a leaning towards the right. The focus on an individual's prediction aligning with Trump's success and the undercurrent of skepticism towards mainstream polling methods imply a criticism of typical left-leaning narratives about the election. The emphasis on Trump's potential victory resonates with a Lean Right perspective, reflecting distrust in the established polling methods often supported by more centrist or left-leaning analysts.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: This article discusses a method to gauge voter sentiment that seems to favor Donald Trump, which suggests a leaning towards the right. The focus on an individual's prediction aligning with Trump's success and the undercurrent of skepticism towards mainstream polling methods imply a criticism of typical left-leaning narratives about the election. The emphasis on Trump's potential victory resonates with a Lean Right perspective, reflecting distrust in the established polling methods often supported by more centrist or left-leaning analysts.

title: California Fast Food Restaurants Shed Thousands of Jobs after $20 Minimum Wage Hike
body: California’s fast food industry shed more than 6,000 jobs after Democratic lawmakers passed a bill mandating a $20 minimum wage for most fast food and counter service restaurants in the state, according to a new analysis of labor data. U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics data show that between September 2023, when California governor Gavin Newsom signed Assembly Bill 1228, and June 2024, Golden State fast food employment dropped from 570,909 jobs to 564,743. That’s a loss of 6,166 jobs, or 1.1 percent, according to an analysis by the nonprofit Employment Policies Institute. During that same period a year earlier, California fast food restaurants added 17,528 jobs, a 3.1 percent increase over those ten months in 2022 and 2023, the data show. “Newsom took a sledgehammer to the state’s restaurants when he signed the $20 fast food minimum wage law,” Rebekah Paxton, EPI’s research director, said in a press release. “Jobs have been smashed by thousands and the industry is struggling to stay afloat.” The fast food minimum wage hike — a 25 percent jump over the $16 minimum wage in place for virtually every other sector of the California economy — was the result of a years-long campaign by Big Labor leaders and their Democratic allies to target an industry they’ve long struggled to organize. In 2022, California Democrats passed the Fast Food Accountability and Standards Recovery Act, or FAST Act, which would have created an unelected fast food council that could have hiked the industry’s minimum wage to $22 an hour. The restaurant industry fought back, gathering enough signatures for a ballot initiative to challenge the act. But Democrats had a fallback plan of their own; last year, for the first time in two decades, they funded what is known as the Industrial Welfare Commission, which has the authority to regulate wages, hours, and working conditions for industries across the state. AB 1228 was a compromise between the fast food industry and lawmakers. In exchange for eliminating the most extreme aspects of the FAST Act, the fast food industry agreed to drop its ballot initiative and raise starting pay to $20 an hour starting April 1, 2024. The $20 minimum wage is in place for fast food restaurants with at least 60 locations nationwide. Ahead of the wage hike, some pizza chains began laying off delivery drivers and farming out delivery operations to third-party apps. Leaders of some chains acknowledged they would raise prices to cover the additional labor costs. Restaurants increasingly turned to technology and robots to increase efficiency and reduce labor costs. Fast food restaurant owners who spoke to National Review last spring said that because of the wage hike, “everything is on the table” in terms of cost cutting. In June, Rubio’s Coastal Grill, a Mexican chain, shuttered 48 of its California restaurants, citing the “rising cost of doing business” in the state. During the ten months when California fast food restaurants slashed 6,000 jobs, employment in fast food restaurants rose 1.6 percent nationwide, according to EPI. And while overall private employment fell slightly in California during that ten-month period, dropping 0.3 percent, the decline was steeper in the fast food industry. In the wake of the fast food wage hike in April, California voters last month rejected Proposition 32, a ballot measure that would have increased the state’s minimum wage from $16 to $18. It was the first time in the state’s history that Californians voted down a ballot measure to increase the statewide minimum wage. Send a tip to the news team at NR.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
This article highlights the negative consequences of a minimum wage increase in California, framing the legislation as harmful to the fast food industry and linking it to job losses. The tone and specific language used, including quotes from industry representatives, indicate a critical stance towards Democratic policies and labor interventions, typical of a Lean Right perspective. The focus on job losses without equally weighing potential benefits suggests a bias favoring concerns of business and economic repercussions.
AI Classification Explanation: This article highlights the negative consequences of a minimum wage increase in California, framing the legislation as harmful to the fast food industry and linking it to job losses. The tone and specific language used, including quotes from industry representatives, indicate a critical stance towards Democratic policies and labor interventions, typical of a Lean Right perspective. The focus on job losses without equally weighing potential benefits suggests a bias favoring concerns of business and economic repercussions.
AI Summary:
California's fast food industry experienced a significant job loss of over 6,000 positions after the state implemented a $20 minimum wage for many fast food and counter service establishments. An analysis by the Employment Policies Institute revealed that from September 2023, when Governor Gavin Newsom signed Assembly Bill 1228, to June 2024, employment in California's fast food sector fell from 570,909 to 564,743 jobs, marking a 1.1 percent decrease. In contrast, during the same period the previous year, the industry had added more than 17,500 jobs.

The $20 minimum wage, a notable 25 percent increase from the previous $16 wage across most sectors, was part of a prolonged initiative by labor leaders and Democrats to organize the fast food industry. The law was a compromise resulting from a fierce political battle, where the state decided not to proceed with more extreme provisions initially proposed in the 2022 FAST Act that would have allowed for a potential $22 minimum wage.

As the new wage took effect, some restaurants began laying off staff and outsourcing delivery services, while others planned price increases to manage labor costs. Across the nation, fast food employment rose 1.6 percent during the same timeframe, even as California's overall private employment saw a slight decline. Additionally, voters in California recently rejected a measure that would have increased the statewide minimum wage, marking the first time such an initiative was voted down in the state’s history.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
This article presents a critical view of California's $20 minimum wage for fast food workers, emphasizing job losses and contrasting data with national employment trends. The language used suggests a focus on economic consequences rather than worker benefits, which aligns more with a lean right perspective. Additionally, referencing the involvement of labor leaders and Democrats in promoting the wage illustrates a critique often found in right-leaning analysis. Overall, the emphasis on negative job impacts and political compromise points toward a more critical stance on progressive labor policies.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: This article presents a critical view of California's $20 minimum wage for fast food workers, emphasizing job losses and contrasting data with national employment trends. The language used suggests a focus on economic consequences rather than worker benefits, which aligns more with a lean right perspective. Additionally, referencing the involvement of labor leaders and Democrats in promoting the wage illustrates a critique often found in right-leaning analysis. Overall, the emphasis on negative job impacts and political compromise points toward a more critical stance on progressive labor policies.

title: Trump Says 'THANK YOU GOD' after Sweeping Last 2 Swing States, Reportedly Taps Rubio for Secretary of State
body: President-elect Donald Trump posted a message of thanks to God on social media after sweeping all seven swing states, getting late tallies in Arizona and Nevada. According to multiple media reports, Trump has tapped Marco Rubio as the next secretary of state. Trump's total victory of 312 votes in the Electoral College is more than he won in 2016. He posted on Truth Social, "THANK YOU GOD! WON ALL SWING STATES, & THE POPULAR VOTE BY ALMOST 7 MILLION VOTERS..." Democrats are fighting over who's to blame for their decisive defeat. Former Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi told The New York Times that if President Biden had relinquished his candidacy sooner, more candidates might have jumped in to create an open primary. Others, like California Rep. Ro Khanna, say the Harris team failed to address the concerns of everyday Americans. "Anyone who's saying now this was not a winnable campaign, didn't say that back in August," he said. "The reason we didn't win ultimately, is that we didn't listen enough to people on the ground... people who were saying talk about the economy, talk about people's economic struggles. Convince people you have the better policies and better vision." Trump Builds New Team and Preps for Transition Florida Senator Marco Rubio, a three-term Republican senator from Florida, is Trump's choice to head the State Department, sources told The New York Times and confirmed to other outlets. The reports came with a caution that Trump could change his mind at the last minute, and Rubio's office has not commented. Meanwhile, the 45th president is working on filling key positions, announcing Sunday that Tom Homan will serve as "border czar." Trump posted on social media that Homan will be "in charge of our Nation's Borders ('The Border Czar'), including, but not limited to, the Southern Border, the Northern Border, all Maritime, and Aviation Security" and oversee a plan to deport immigrants who entered the U.S. illegally. Homan served as acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement in Trump's first term. On Monday, Trump also named his longtime adviser Stephen Miller, another immigration hard-liner, to be his deputy chief of policy. In addition, New York Rep. Elise Stefanik has been chosen to serve as ambassador to the United Nations and New York Rep. Lee Zeldin will serve as the administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency. Trump also announced two people who won't be serving in his administration, posting on social media that Nikki Haley and Mike Pompeo won't be asked to join his team.Both served in his first administration: Haley as ambassador to the U.N. and Pompeo as Secretary of State. Haley strongly criticized her former boss when she ran against him in the Republican primaries. New Senate Leadership as GOP Takes Over Confirming President Trump's cabinet will be the first priority of the new Republican Senate. The GOP took control of the body from the Democrats and now holds 53 seats. This week, they're moving to establish leadership. GOP Senate leader Mitch McConnell is stepping down after 17 years as head of the Senate Republican conference. Wednesday they'll vote on his replacement. Sens. John Cornyn of Texas, John Thune of South Dakota, and Rick Scott of Florida are vying for the position. Wyoming's Sen. John Barrasso is expected to take the number two slot as majority whip. Sunday on NBC's 'Meet the Press', Barrasso said the Senate will move swiftly to approve Trump's nominees. "He met huge resistance in 2016 and in 2017 getting his cabinet in place. What I'm hoping is in light of this huge landslide victory that we get a little more cooperation from the Democrats to get that cabinet in place on day one." Sunday, Trump demanded that all candidates for Senate leader must agree to recess appointments. The temporary measure allows the president to directly appoint nominees when Congress is not in session.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article primarily presents information favorable to Donald Trump, including his expressions of gratitude and his cabinet appointments. It emphasizes Republican leadership and success in the Senate, while also addressing Democratic criticisms, which could suggest a more neutral tone. However, the overall focus on Trump’s achievements and the portrayal of the GOP’s plans lend a lean towards a right-leaning bias.
AI Classification Explanation: The article primarily presents information favorable to Donald Trump, including his expressions of gratitude and his cabinet appointments. It emphasizes Republican leadership and success in the Senate, while also addressing Democratic criticisms, which could suggest a more neutral tone. However, the overall focus on Trump’s achievements and the portrayal of the GOP’s plans lend a lean towards a right-leaning bias.
AI Summary:
President-elect Donald Trump expressed his gratitude to God on social media after winning all seven swing states, securing a total of 312 Electoral College votes—more than he achieved in 2016. He announced his victory, including a nearly 7 million vote margin in the popular vote, via a post on Truth Social. Meanwhile, Democrats are grappling with the reasons behind their loss, with figures like Nancy Pelosi and Rep. Ro Khanna highlighting missed opportunities and communication failures regarding economic issues.

Trump has reportedly selected Florida Senator Marco Rubio to be the next Secretary of State, although this decision may change. In conjunction with his transition, Trump is appointing Tom Homan as "border czar" to oversee U.S. borders and immigration policy, backed by Stephen Miller as deputy chief of policy. Additionally, he named Rep. Elise Stefanik as U.N. ambassador and Rep. Lee Zeldin as head of the EPA, while confirming that Nikki Haley and Mike Pompeo won't return to his administration.

In the Senate, Republicans have regained control with a 53-seat advantage and are prioritizing the confirmation of Trump's cabinet. Mitch McConnell is stepping down as Senate Republican leader, with potential successors including John Cornyn, John Thune, and Rick Scott. Senate leadership is expected to move quickly to approve Trump's nominees, and he has requested that all candidates for Senate leader back the use of recess appointments to expedite the process.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article primarily focuses on the actions and decisions of Donald Trump and his administration while highlighting the Republican Party's regained control in the Senate. It presents a more favorable view of Trump's victory and cabinet selections without an extensive critique of his policies or decisions. The inclusion of Democrats' struggles is more of a side note, indicating a trend towards a right-leaning perspective, which emphasizes Republican achievements and minimizes critical analysis of their implications.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article primarily focuses on the actions and decisions of Donald Trump and his administration while highlighting the Republican Party's regained control in the Senate. It presents a more favorable view of Trump's victory and cabinet selections without an extensive critique of his policies or decisions. The inclusion of Democrats' struggles is more of a side note, indicating a trend towards a right-leaning perspective, which emphasizes Republican achievements and minimizes critical analysis of their implications.

title: Hero 6th-grader comforted younger students when gunman opened fire: ‘Take deep breaths and think of something happy’
body: A heroic sixth-grader comforted younger pupils when a gunman opened fire in their tiny California Christian school Wednesday — even as she feared for her own life. Jocelyn Orlando stepped up to help despite her own terror as the shooter struck — critically wounding a 5 and 6-year-old — just feet away from her at Feather River School of Seventh-Day Adventists in Palermo. 3 Jocelyn Orlando helped her terrified younger schoolmates stay calm during the shooting. CBS News “I was thinking to myself, what if I get shot, what will happen to my family and me,” she told CBS13. She heard the gunshots and screams as she and others were returning from lunch recess. Swallowing her fears, the sixth grader stepped up to try and calm the younger students panicking around her. 1/1 Skip Ad Continue watchingafter the adVisit Advertiser websiteGO TO PAGE“I told the kindergarteners to take deep breaths — just think of something happy,” Jocelyn said. “I told the little graders to close their eyes and cover their ears” as the gunman was menacingly “pacing back and forth from the window.” Explore More UnitedHealthcare CEO was facing DOJ probe for insider trading when he was killed in targeted NYC shooting Message on bullets fired by health care CEO's assassin bears eerie link to book condemning insurance companies Tsunami warning sparks panic along West Coast after 7.0-magnitude earthquake — before being canceled 3 A 5 and 6-year-old were shot at the Feather River Adventist School. AP The shooter, who has yet to be identified, managed to strike the two young boys, before turning the gun on himself. “It was really, really sad,” the brave sixth-grade witness said. The shot boys were taken to a hospital, one by helicopter in “extremely critical condition,” Butte County Sheriff Kory Honea said. 3 The gunman took his own life near the school playground, officials said. AP The gunman had gained access to the school — which only has 35 students — for a meeting with the principal about potentially enrolling a student. “Shortly after concluding that meeting, the principal heard shots being fired, heard screams, and that’s when they determined or found that the two students had been shot,” Honea said. 9What do you think? Post a comment. He is not believed to have any connection to the school or the students — but may have targeted the school because of its affiliation with the Seventh-Day Adventist Church. The One In Five Foundation For Kids, formerly The Uvalde Foundation For Kids, announced on Thursday that they would be awarding Orlando with an award for her courage during the shooting, CBS13 reported.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Center  
The article presents factual reporting of a tragic event without evident political bias or leaning towards a particular ideological stance. It focuses solely on the heroic actions of a student during a school shooting, including details such as the identities and conditions of the individuals involved. The writer does not engage in attributing blame or advocating for specific policies related to gun control or other socio-political issues, maintaining an objective tone throughout.
AI Classification Explanation: The article presents factual reporting of a tragic event without evident political bias or leaning towards a particular ideological stance. It focuses solely on the heroic actions of a student during a school shooting, including details such as the identities and conditions of the individuals involved. The writer does not engage in attributing blame or advocating for specific policies related to gun control or other socio-political issues, maintaining an objective tone throughout.
AI Summary: In a tragic incident at the Feather River School of Seventh-Day Adventists in California, a sixth-grader named Jocelyn Orlando displayed remarkable bravery when a gunman opened fire, critically injuring two young boys aged 5 and 6. The shooter, who later took his own life, had entered the school under the pretense of a meeting with the principal about enrolling a student. As gunfire erupted, Jocelyn, despite her own fears, comforted her terrified younger classmates by encouraging them to take deep breaths and think of happy thoughts. Witnessing the chaos, she instructed them to close their eyes and cover their ears as the shooter paced ominously nearby. The wounded children were transported to a hospital, with one in extremely critical condition. The gunman, who had no known ties to the school, may have targeted it due to its religious affiliation. In recognition of her bravery during the crisis, Jocelyn is set to receive an award from the One In Five Foundation For Kids.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Center  
The article presents a straightforward report on a tragic incident without explicit political framing or commentary. It focuses on the events that occurred at the school, highlighting the bravery of a young hero while also mentioning the shooter’s actions and the incident's implications. The absence of political language or advocacy for specific policies regarding gun control or school safety allows it to fit into a center classification, prioritizing facts and human interest over bias.

It focuses on the events that occurred at the school, highlighting the bravery of a young hero while also mentioning the shooter’s actions and the incident's implications. The absence of political language or advocacy for specific policies regarding gun control or school safety allows it to fit into a center classification, prioritizing facts and human interest over bias.

title: EXCLUSIVE: Team Trump Promises Cabinet Nominees Will ‘Make America Safe Again’
body: President Donald Trump’s cabinet nominees will “Make America Safe Again,” the president’s team said in a video first obtained by The Daily Wire.The video highlights the qualifications of Trump cabinet nominees Kristi Noem, Pam Bondi, Kash Patel, and Tom Homan, arguing that they bring a vast array of experience to the table — and that they will support Trump’s agenda to end the weaponization of the government against the American people, secure the border, and more.“President Trump was given a mandate to Make America Safe Again by securing our border, prosecuting dangerous criminals, supporting our police and Border Patrol, and rooting out corruption and crime,” Trump-Vance transition spokeswoman Karoline Leavitt told The Daily Wire. “President Trump’s nominees exemplify the leadership and experience needed to ensure the safety and security of all Americans.”WATCH:Advertisement“From Governor Kristi Noem’s proven record of upholding the rule of law, to Pam Bondi’s in combating crime and drug trafficking, these appointees are poised to restore integrity and justice across the nation,” Leavitt added. “Kash Patel’s expertise in protecting Americans from a range of threats and Tom Homan’s unflinching efforts on border enforcement demonstrate their readiness to tackle the challenges ahead. Together, they form a team dedicated to protecting our communities, securing our freedoms, and Making America Safe Again.”Noem is the governor of South Dakota, where the Trump team touts her work with the Department of Homeland Security, noting that she was the first governor to deploy National Guard soldiers to Texas to combat border crisis, which she did on seven other occasions. Florida Attorney General Pam Bondi has spent more than 18 years as a prosecutor and was the state’s first female attorney general.Homan is the former acting director of Immigration and Customs Enforcement (ICE), and has a long history of service with the department. And Patel is the former chief of staff at the Department of Defense as well as the former Deputy Director of National Intelligence. Patel would be the first public defender to serve as director of the FBI, the Trump transition team said.AdvertisementThe video quotes Republican Tennessee Sen. Marsha Blackburn promising that Trump and his administration will not tolerate criminal activity at the United States border.“You’re going to see a very strong Kristi Noem at Homeland Security and Homan on the Border,” she says. “We’re going to get this issue under control, and I can assure you they will have the backing of the U.S. House and U.S. Senate as they carry forward on this work.”Similarly, Florida Rep. Cory Mills (R.) argues that “Kash has seen from the inside with his qualifications and his time in the Administration what type of weaponization has gone forward, and he’s going to clean up the FBI.”Advertisement“Pam Bondi coming on as Attorney General is going to clean up the Department of ‘InJustice,'” he adds. “We’re going to have real rule of law, not the weaponization you see under this corrupt administration.”The video also features Fox News host Sean Hannity arguing that Bondi is a “terrific nomination for many, many reasons.”“Pam worked as a prosecutor for nearly two decades, was the first woman elected – two-time elected – Attorney General for the great State of Florida where she served for 8 years,” Hannity says. “Pam Bondi known for being tough on crime, worked hard to curb drug trafficking… pill mills in Florida, and during her tenure Florida became one of the safest states in the country.”Fox News host Brian Kilmeade is also featured praising Homan as “impressive,” arguing: “he’s been successful with Republicans and Democrats. In fact, up until Donald Trump took over, before that, you’d have no idea where he stood politically.”Advertisement
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Right  
The article leans towards a right-wing perspective, primarily supporting President Trump and his cabinet nominees while portraying them as competent and dedicated to law and order. It employs positive language to highlight the nominees' qualifications and their alignment with Trump’s agenda, indicating a clear bias that favors the Republican viewpoint. The reliance on Republican voices and quotations further strengthens its right-leaning stance.
AI Classification Explanation: The article leans towards a right-wing perspective, primarily supporting President Trump and his cabinet nominees while portraying them as competent and dedicated to law and order. It employs positive language to highlight the nominees' qualifications and their alignment with Trump’s agenda, indicating a clear bias that favors the Republican viewpoint. The reliance on Republican voices and quotations further strengthens its right-leaning stance.
AI Summary:
In a video obtained by The Daily Wire, President Donald Trump's team promises that his cabinet nominees will "Make America Safe Again." The nominees include Kristi Noem, Pam Bondi, Kash Patel, and Tom Homan, all of whom are described as highly qualified and aligned with Trump's agenda to combat government weaponization, secure the border, and address crime. 

Karoline Leavitt, a spokesperson, emphasized that Trump's team will focus on restoring integrity and protecting communities, referencing Noem's deployment of National Guard troops to the Texas border, Bondi's extensive prosecutorial career, Homan's leadership in ICE, and Patel's background in national intelligence. 

Support from Republican leaders like Sen. Marsha Blackburn and Rep. Cory Mills is showcased, affirming their confidence in the nominees to handle border issues and reform the FBI and Justice Department. Additionally, Fox News personalities praised Bondi for her successful tenure as Florida's Attorney General and Homan for his bipartisan effectiveness.
Raw AI Summary Bias Detection:
Lean Right  
The article showcases President Trump's cabinet nominees positively, highlighting their qualifications and endorsement from Republican leaders, which indicates a favorable bias towards conservative viewpoints. The focus on their alignment with Trump's agenda and the supportive quotes from GOP figures suggest a leaning towards right-wing perspectives rather than a neutral or left-leaning view.
AI Summary Classification Explanation: The article showcases President Trump's cabinet nominees positively, highlighting their qualifications and endorsement from Republican leaders, which indicates a favorable bias towards conservative viewpoints. The focus on their alignment with Trump's agenda and the supportive quotes from GOP figures suggest a leaning towards right-wing perspectives rather than a neutral or left-leaning view.

title: Ron DeSantis Could Be Getting Another Season on the Trump Show
body: Nominating Fox News personality Pete Hegseth to be secretary of defense was, from the start, one of the least serious choices Donald Trump made in assembling his broadly unserious slate of second-term Cabinet nominees. But information that has come out since Hegseth’s nomination was announced makes the selection look even less responsible. A newly published police report shows that he was accused of sexually assaulting and possibly raping a woman he met at a 2017 conference in California. (Local authorities concluded that there was not enough evidence available to bring charges, and he denies the allegation.) A New Yorker investigation found that he was forced out of two jobs leading veterans’ groups over “serious allegations of financial mismanagement, sexual impropriety, and personal misconduct” that included being heavily intoxicated at work events. (Hegseth’s attorney told the magazine that the claims were “outlandish” and blamed “a petty and jealous disgruntled former associate” for circulating them.) And the New York Times obtained an email written to Hegseth in 2018 by his mother in which she described him as someone who “lies, cheats, sleeps around and uses women for his own power and ego.” (Hegseth, 44, has been married three times. His mother says she regrets writing the email and that it does not fairly characterize her son.) The allegations themselves are obviously not disqualifying per se to Trump, who was found liable last year for defaming a woman that the jury determined he had raped in 1996, and was found guilty this year of committing fraud to cover up evidence of a sexual affair conducted soon after his third wife gave birth to their child. But he is reportedly peeved that Hegseth did not tell his transition team about the rape allegation, and has a long-standing suspicion of heavy drinkers that derives from his late brother Fred’s alcoholism. In fact, both the Wall Street Journal and the New York Times are now reporting that Trump is annoyed enough with Hegseth, and skeptical enough of his chances of being confirmed, that he is considering bringing back a beloved character from previous seasons of the Trump Show to take the SecDef role instead: Yes … YES!!!! That’s our Meatball Ron, who rose to the dizzying heights of running about even with Trump in presidential primary polls on the strength of his campaigns against COVID precautions and wokeness … but then fell back to the dismal depths of having to actually manage the state of Florida after voters discovered that he is an awkward, over-scripted campaigner so ineffective that when Slate ran a piece about political strategists’ suggestions for improving his chances, we concluded that his two best options were “dropping out or becoming a different person.” He also once allegedly ate a cup of pudding with his fingers on an airplane. You’ve got Meatball Questions, we’ve got Meatball Answers: • But what about all the harsh things that DeSantis said about Trump during the primary, many of which were quite obviously true? Old stuff doesn’t matter that much to Trump so long as someone is willing to suck up to him in the present. • Is he qualified for the role? DeSantis served when he was younger as a Navy “JAG,” or judge advocate general, deploying to Iraq. While he never held a major leadership role in the military, by Trump administration standards, he is basically Dwight Eisenhower. • Would he actually want to do this? Sure—eliminating “wokeness” (i.e., diversity programs) from American institutions, including the military, has long been DeSantis’ main goal as a politician. It’s also an important and high-profile job and he probably wants to run for president again. • Is anyone else under consideration? Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst—who would be a much more qualified candidate, but also a less funny one—reportedly is. So that’s the lay of the land. And the stakes are high: In a normal administration, the secretary of defense is responsible for supervising the operations and maintaining the readiness of the United States’ armed forces, but in Trump administrations, he or she holds the even more important job of persuading the president not to invade Mexico, install himself as king, or order the special forces to conduct a “smash-and-grab extraction” of Rosie O’Donnell. Stay careful out there, folks.
Raw AI Bias Detection:
Lean Left  
The article displays a critical tone towards Donald Trump and his potential cabinet nominee, Pete Hegseth, highlighting allegations of misconduct and contrasting their governance style with what is deemed as serious and responsible. The use of informal language such as "Trump Show" and descriptors like "unserious" reflects a more liberal perspective. Additionally, the references to “wokeness” and criticism of Republican figures suggest a leaning against mainstream conservative ideologies, characteristic of left-leaning media.
AI Classification Explanation: The article displays a critical tone towards Donald Trump and his potential cabinet nominee, Pete Hegseth, highlighting allegations of misconduct and contrasting their governance style with what is deemed as serious and responsible. The use of informal language such as "Trump Show" and descriptors like "unserious" reflects a more liberal perspective. Additionally, the references to “wokeness” and criticism of Republican figures suggest a leaning against mainstream conservative ideologies, characteristic of left-leaning media.
AI Summary:
Donald Trump’s nomination of Fox News figure Pete Hegseth for the secretary of defense role has come under scrutiny following new allegations of sexual misconduct and leadership failures from his past. Hegseth faced accusations of sexually assaulting a woman in 2017, leading to a police report, though no charges were filed, and he denies the allegation. An investigation by New Yorker revealed he was pushed out from two veterans’ groups due to serious misconduct and financial mismanagement. Additionally, an email from Hegseth's mother described him as deceitful and egotistical, although she later regretted her words.

Trump's past controversies, including being found liable for defamation related to a rape case, may not disqualify Hegseth in Trump's eyes, but the former president reportedly is frustrated that Hegseth did not disclose the allegations and has a distrust of heavy drinkers. As a result, Trump is reconsidering the nomination, potentially bringing back Ron DeSantis, who has experience as a Navy JAG and shares Trump's goal to eliminate "wokeness" from military practices. DeSantis has faced his share of challenges as a campaigner, revealing an awkward persona that may raise questions about his suitability for the role. Other candidates, such as Iowa Sen. Joni Ernst, are also being considered. The secretary of defense plays a crucial role in advising the president on national security and military readiness.
